Climate data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Weather Bureau for December of 1931 shows no precipitation near Miami or Superior in the week leading up to Dec. 24. High temperatures were in the 60s, and the lows had not dipped below freezing for at least a week.

While it’s possible Ed was referring to snow on the surrounding mountains, they likely would have had a much better view of the snow on Four Peaks at their earlier stop in Roosevelt.

There is no record of whether the authorities tried to verify that Julia visited a friend in Roosevelt. Census records, voter registration rolls and city directories show no Mrs. Houser — or any other variation of that spelling — in Roosevelt or the surrounding area.

The only Houser listed is 30 miles away — in Miami.

There are other questions about the Stewarts' testimony that apparently went unasked.

Both Ed and Julia testified that they broke down seven miles west of Superior, a busy mining town that was then significantly larger than Mesa. Neither Green nor Truman asked why they didn’t drive the seven miles back to Superior instead of driving the 40 miles to Mesa.

The Stewarts testified that they heated water from a Thermos and fed it to the baby in a spoon. But later in her testimony, Julia said she did not stay with her husband at the police station because she had left her own 8-month-old baby with her mother and was uncomfortable because she had not nursed all day.

Perhaps it was the decorum of the time, but neither Green nor Truman asked her why she didn’t nurse the foundling during the 2-hour drive back to Mesa.

◆ Julia Stewart changes her story

A year later, journalist and author Oren Arnold interviewed Julia for an anniversary story about the Hatbox Baby.

Both Stewarts testified in court that their car broke down with a fuel line problem. In Arnold’s story, however, Julia said they had a flat tire.

“We were put out when that tire went flat,” she told Arnold.

“We had an eight-month-old baby of our own back in Mesa with my mother, and Ed and I were anxious to get back and take of Santa Clause.”

And while she had initially testified that they never stopped after Roosevelt, she told Arnold that “Business had called us to Superior that day.”

"Ed got out to change the tire," she said. "The air was cold and still and to keep from shivering I got out and walked around. The stars were awfully bright on the desert, and I remember that it all looked like pictures you see on Christmas cards…”

“I walked a way on the desert from the highway, while Ed was knocking and banging on the wheel. Suddenly I saw something black on the ground near a greasewood bush. It didn’t frighten me. I just saw it looked odd, so I called Ed.

“He hollered back that he was in a hurry to get home, and was about done with the tire.

“But I made him come anyway. When we went closer, we saw it was a ragged hatbox…It was closed, and a piece of cloth hung out.

“Ed opened it, and something inside moved! Then I did get scared. I clutched at Ed’s shoulder. We heard a little noise.

“We carefully pulled back the cloth, and as Ed struck a match we saw it was a teeny baby! I never felt so queer in all my life.”

If Arnold, who later wrote that he attended the adoption hearing, caught the discrepancies, it’s not evident from his story.

◆ A letter from the Stewarts

In the end, Green declared the Hatbox Baby abandoned and eligible for adoption. While an occasional newspaper columnist would write a wistful column wondering whatever became of the baby, it would be 55 years before anyone found out.

The world would learn that her name was Sharon Elliott, and, after I wrote the first story about her in 1988, a private investigator named Alice Syman helped get her story on "Unsolved Mysteries."

The Stewarts were never interviewed for the program.

Several years after it aired, Syman wrote them, asking for their side of the story.

“I have thought about you so many times, and have wanted to tell you how sorry I am for any discomfort you may have sustained by what was said on the show,” she wrote. “We never meant to hurt anyone.”

The Stewarts would have none of it.

“You know as much about the Hatbox Baby as we do. We FOUND her, we know NOTHING about her,” Julia wrote. “We question why she would care who her mother is, when she took her to the desert & and left her for the wild animals to eat. As far as we’re concerned, this matter is CLOSED!! Please DO NOT contact us again.”

Ed Stewart died in 1992, and Julia died 10 years later.

It would take nearly 20 years before DNA testing would show no genetic link between the Stewarts and the baby they said they found in a hatbox in the middle of the desert on Christmas Eve of 1931.

But the questions about whether there was more to their tale than they were telling would remain.

The people who gave Sharon a home

On July 18, 1986, Faith Morrow filed a motion in Pinal County Superior Court, asking a judge to unseal the adoption records in the 55-year-old case of the Hatbox Baby.

“I am now 83 and my daughter will be 55 in December,” she wrote in a shaky hand. “I feel I could better tell her she is adopted than to have some other person (well-meaning or otherwise) tell her after I am gone.”

Faith told the judge how two years earlier while undergoing treatment for breast cancer, the radiation burned the lining of her heart, almost killing her. She had also fallen and broken a hip and undergone hip-replacement surgery.

She felt her own mortality closing in on her, and she wanted to tell her daughter the secret she’d kept from her for more than half a century.

It was even more urgent because her daughter was thinking of moving to Mesa, and Faith was afraid she might accidentally stumble across the story of her birth there.

In six months, Faith would be dead.

In her motion, Faith described how, years earlier, she and her husband, Henry, desperately wanted to have a child but that she had not been able to carry a baby to term.

“Following yet another miscarriage…I was beginning to think I would never have a baby of my own,” she wrote.

“When I heard the news on the radio (Christmas morning) we turned off the oven on the turkey and drove right to Mesa to see the baby. You should have seen her — so perfect and so perfectly adorable.

“We requested the right to adopt her. I was told they had 200 applications.”

I found Faith’s motion in Sharon’s adoption records after I filed my own motion in Pinal County Superior Court in November to have them unsealed. Faith’s motion had been successful, but for some reason, the records had been resealed.

I had some items from the original file, but I wanted to make sure there weren’t other clues that we might not have known were relevant 30 years ago, well before anyone thought of DNA testing for the Hatbox Baby.

I had introduced her in a story as Sharon Elliott, a retired aerospace worker from Southern California who never knew she was adopted, much less the subject of a longstanding Arizona mystery.

In my court hearing on Dec. 5, Pinal County Superior Court Judge Stephen McCarville told me he’d read the file and didn’t think there was much in there that I didn’t already have. He granted my motion to unseal the file.

Then he wished me luck.

“I hope you find what you’re looking for,” he said.

He was right. I knew most of what was in the file, but there were a couple of things I didn’t: Faith’s five-page handwritten motion, and a transcript of her testimony in the Feb. 10, 1932 adoption hearing for the Hatbox Baby (who was known at the time as Baby Marian, named for the Virgin Mary because she was found on Christmas Eve).

After she was adopted, her new parents changed her name to Mary Elizabeth. Sharon didn’t remember when exactly her name had changed again, but she always thought it had something to do with the Rose of Sharon, a flowering vine that is mentioned in the Bible, and the fact that Faith’s father was a minister.

The adoption documents helped me flesh out a picture of Faith, a complicated woman who led a complicated life. While she was the only mother Sharon ever knew, Sharon never had much to say about her other than what a normal upbringing she had had and what a good mother Faith was to her and her stepbrother.

But in digging into Faith’s life, I found things out about her that Sharon never knew, including a marriage and a divorce, and Faith’s apparent use of aliases in at least two sets of public records.

◆ Who was Faith Morrow?

Faith Lillian Amelia Soderstrom was born in Minnesota in 1903, the youngest child of an itinerant Swedish-born preacher. By age 7, her family had moved to Alamogordo, N.M., and by 16 she was living in a Los Angeles boarding house with her mother, who worked as a housekeeper for a woman who had lived in Arizona.

Less than a year later, Faith was living near Prescott, possibly to be with her sister, whose husband, a World War I veteran, was being treated at Fort Whipple. The post had a large Army sanatorium that treated soldiers for tuberculosis or complications from mustard-gas exposure in the trenches.

Fort Whipple was founded in 1864 during what were known as the Indian Wars, and actually served as Arizona’s first territorial capital before a more permanent seat of government was established two miles south in Prescott. The fort was active through the Spanish American War, protecting the capital as well as the gold mines that dot the area.

The fort was decommissioned in the early 1900s, then recommissioned during World War I.

Soon after she arrived in Prescott, Faith went to work as a clerk typist and stenographer for the Veteran’s Bureau at Fort Whipple, and in 1925, at the age of 22, she married a man named Sigmund Ingersoll, who also worked at the fort and was nearly 10 years her senior.

The marriage didn’t last. Less than three years later, in March 1928, she would divorce him, citing non-support and the fact that he didn’t want children.

Sharon Elliott never knew about that divorce until I found a copy in the state archives and asked her about it. The news didn’t seem to faze her. Compared to finding out she was the Hatbox Baby, that surprise was pretty minor, she told me.

In Faith’s divorce complaint, she alleges that “for more than one year last past (Ingersoll) has neglected and failed to provide…the common necessaries of life, he having the ability to provide the same but has failed by reason of his idleness, profligacy and dissipation,” even though he was a “strong, able-bodied man, able to provide a living for himself and is now earning more than $150 a month.”

“I worked all the time we were married and gave him practically every penny I made,” she said.

Ingersoll never bothered to answer the complaint or show up in court. Faith said it was probably because he was afraid he’d be hit with the court costs.

By the time her divorce was granted in March of 1928, Faith had already moved to Phoenix. The 1928 Phoenix City Directory shows a woman named Ingersoll working as a typist at the Veteran's Bureau, but she is listed as Fanny, not Faith.

◆ Who was Sharon's adoptive father?

On Oct. 25, 1928, Faith would marry Henry Stieg in Los Angeles. She could not legally marry in Arizona because not enough time had elapsed since her divorce.

Stieg was an up-and-coming grocery executive who would go on to become one of the Valley’s movers and shakers. Stieg was one of the founding directors of the A.J. Bayless grocery chain, which was an Arizona mainstay for 60 years until it was absorbed in the grocery consolidations of the 1990s.

Stieg's was a rags-to-riches story, the kind that gave Phoenix a reputation as a place where anyone could stake a claim to a fresh start and succeed beyond their wildest imagination. Born in poverty in rural southwestern Ohio, he attended school only through sixth grade.

His father was a farmer and a “coal burner,” the tough, grimy job of making charcoal, which was commonly used for heat. His mother, who had divorced his father, worked as a housekeeper, and when Henry was old enough to work, she sold him into virtual servitude, an arrangement where she was paid for the work he did for a neighboring farmer.

As a teenager, he began selling fruits and vegetables in Hamilton, Ohio, near Cincinnati, and parlayed it into a going concern. By his early 20s, he was buying quarter-page advertisements in the Hamilton newspaper on a weekly basis.

Like Faith, Stieg had a failed marriage in his past. He’d married at 19 and had a son. They moved to Arizona sometime between 1925 and 1927, when she moved back to Ohio.

Four years later, Stieg would testify at Sharon’s adoption hearing that he divorced his wife on grounds of desertion, but it’s unclear whether she could have sued him on grounds of infidelity.

“She knew I carried on and she went back to Ohio and I wouldn’t go back. I was in business here…and she wouldn’t stay … because it was too hot in Arizona and I wouldn’t go back to Ohio, so we separated."

Both Henry and Faith told the judge that they were happily married and had never discussed or even contemplated divorce.

They told Green they lived in a house on two and a half acres on McDowell Road just east of the city limits. They said the house and the property were worth $5,500 and they only owed $1,000 on it. Henry also testified that he had 600 shares of A.J. Bayless stock and made $45 a week plus a bonus.

It was just two years after the stock market crash of 1929, when unemployment was 17 percent, and Henry Stieg, at the age of 29, was making 25 percent more than the average American.

◆ 'Let it rest a miracle'

While news reports at the time said that as many as 200 couples had wanted to adopt the Hatbox Baby, only two showed up. Heavy rains that week had made travel difficult.

The other couple, a 45-year-old employee of Hayden Flour Mill and his 36-year-old wife, already had a 14-year-old adopted daughter.

Court transcripts from the Feb. 10, 1932, adoption hearing show a fairly routine procedure, but Faith’s own account years later, along with that of Arizona Republic reporter Oren Arnold, bend toward the dramatic.

“The judge called them first, and the woman didn’t say anything but the man said, 'We have one adopted daughter and I’ll say right here she’s been raised in the fear of the Lord, and I don’t believe in sparing the rod and spoiling the child," Faith wrote in her 1986 motion, recounting the testimony of the other couple. “I prayed — Dear God don’t let that man have my baby!”

At the end of the day, Judge Green allowed the Stiegs to adopt the Hatbox Baby because they did not have a child while the other family did.

Thirty years later, Arnold wrote in the Christmas 1952 issue of Desert Magazine that he too was in the courtroom that day and that Faith had begged the judge to “Never tell where Marian is. Let her grow up without publicity, not as a freak found out on the desert. Please never tell.”

Arnold closed his piece by saying he had been in contact with Faith and that the Hatbox Baby was well and happy.

“It has all been so wonderful,” Faith told him. “People are so kind. Let it rest as a miracle. Please never tell who she is or where she is.”

◆ ◆ ◆

Faith and Henry finally had the baby they’d always wanted. But their domestic bliss wouldn’t last, and there are indications it was just fiction anyway. Just seven months after they adopted Baby Marian, Henry Stieg filed for divorce. His wife was already living back in Prescott at the time.

In his petition, Henry accused Faith of “cruel treatment,” saying that for more than a year, “she constantly and without reason found fault with and quarreled with (him), both in private and before his friends and acquaintances.”

She also mocked his “manner of speech” and “lack of education,” causing him “constant discomfort, annoyance and mental pain and anguish.”

Lastly, Henry said that Faith “consistently disturbed (his) peace of mind and the enjoyment of his home, by constantly urging and insisting” that Henry quit his job and move to California, where she preferred to live.

The divorce was granted. Henry agreed to pay Faith $1,500 in monthly installments of $50 for her share of the house and gave her a 1929 Buick sedan. She also got to keep her Singer sewing machine, the couple’s dishware — and their baby.

Their settlement called for Faith to have sole custody and control of the baby, now identified as Mary Elizabeth Stieg, and in return she agreed to forgo any alimony or child support.

Henry Stieg went on to become a prominent Phoenix citizen. He ran a number of businesses, including a bar and restaurant and a meat-packing company that was accused by a disgruntled business partner — charges never proven — of selling horsemeat to the Scottsdale schools while his third wife served on the school board.

His third marriage would come 10 years after his divorce from Faith, and he and his new wife would adopt four children together.

If Henry Stieg ever saw Sharon after his divorce from Faith, Sharon didn't remember it.

◆ ◆ ◆

After her divorce from Henry, Faith returned to the Veteran’s Bureau at Fort Whipple, and less than 20 months later, she married for a third time, this time to a tuberculosis patient named Charles Francis Cook, a second lieutenant from New York who had fought in World War I.

Cook was a widower. His wife had died of tuberculosis several years earlier, leaving behind a young son, Jack. Almost a year to the day after he and Faith married, Charles Cook died, leaving Faith with a daughter and a son, and, after a fight, his veteran’s pension.

Prescott city directories from the late 1930s show Faith Cook, and Jack and Sharon, living in a home owned by a music teacher, Vera Morrow, and her brother Arthur, who is listed as a house painter.

Arthur, who was four years older than Faith, was tall and thin, with blue eyes and brown hair. On March 7, 1939, a marriage license was issued in his name in Yuma. He married a woman named “Esther Cook,” whose age and birthplace match Faith’s.

A year later, Faith Cook is listed in the 1940 Census as a widow, living in Los Angeles with her children, Jack Cook and Sharon Stieg; along with Vera and Arthur, who was listed as a carpenter.

His World War II draft registration card lists him as working for Airesearch, an aerospace company in Inglewood, Calif, where he spent the rest of his career, helping raise Sharon and Jack. He would give Sharon away at her wedding.

In her 1986 court plea to have Sharon's adoption records unsealed, Faith mentions that she was divorced from Henry, but says that she and Arthur were married for 40 years. She doesn't mention the marriage to Charles Cook at all.

Arthur Morrow died in 1979, the only father Sharon ever knew.

The search for Edna Sherman Roe

As Christmas approached in 2011, I started thinking about Sharon Elliott, who was about to celebrate her 80th birthday and 80 years as the center of one of Arizona's most enduring mysteries.

I called her and told her I'd like to do another story.

If anyone involved in her case was left, their memories would be fading. I hoped another story might pry another clue loose. She was willing to give it a shot.

“The Hatbox Baby is 80 now," I wrote, "and I’ve come to interview her again.”

As I had many times before, I sat down with Sharon at her kitchen table and began to sort through the box of clippings and documents that chronicled the extraordinary first few days of her life.

There were news stories from across the country that recounted how a young couple making their way from Superior to Mesa on Christmas Eve of 1931 pulled over in the middle of the desert with car trouble and found the baby stuffed in a black pasteboard hatbox.

There were the records of her adoption, two months later, after authorities failed to find any trace of who might have left her in the desert or why.

There was even the first story I wrote about her in 1988.

And then there was an envelope.

◆ A note hidden in plain sight

I was certain I’d never seen it before. It looked unfamiliar to Sharon.

Inside was a single page with a series of notations, written with almost no punctuation in a woman’s hand that Sharon identified as her adoptive mother’s.

“Mother Edna Sherman Roe,” it said.

“Born 1914 Died 1949 Plane crash.”

And then this: “1935 — your mother saw you she was 21 then.”

I was stunned.

I had first written about Sharon’s case nearly a quarter of a century earlier. Had the solution to the mystery of the Hatbox Baby been beneath our noses all this time?

“That’s my mother’s handwriting,” Sharon said. “How could I have missed it?”

In 1986, when Sharon was 55, her adoptive mother, Faith Morrow, was dying of cancer. Before she did, she told Sharon the secret she had kept since Sharon was a baby.

Not only was Sharon adopted, but she was the Hatbox Baby.

Faith gave Sharon an envelope of old, yellowed newspaper clippings and other documents that laid out how Sharon was found, declared abandoned and placed up for adoption.

When I showed Sharon the envelope, she couldn’t say whether it had been in the stack of newspaper clippings Faith had given her, or whether she found it after Faith had died.

There was another complication. In an effort to keep Sharon from finding the documents, Faith had given them to friends and relatives for safekeeping. The last friend who had them, Dorothy Wooden, misplaced them for several years. She thought she had accidentally thrown them out, but then found them again.

Could the letter have come from someone other than Faith?

I called Alice Syman, a private investigator who helped land Sharon’s case on the TV show "Unsolved Mysteries" who had taken Sharon to Pinal County to view her adoption file after I wrote the first Hatbox Baby story in 1988.

Alice had spent thousands of hours on Sharon’s case and felt she had seen the letter. According to her detailed notes from the case, she had tracked down relatives of Edna Sherman Roe, but none of them knew anything about her having a baby. Her files even contained a picture, but Alice didn't believe there was a family resemblance.

Still, it was worth looking into again, she suggested.

◆ ◆ ◆

The first thing I did was to Google Edna Sherman Roe. The search turned up a 1953 U.S. Supreme Court Case involving the beneficiaries of her life insurance policy.

She and her husband, an executive at a tool and dye company in Odessa, Texas, had indeed been killed when the small plane he was flying crashed in the mountains near Ruidoso, New Mexico. But the crash was in 1951, not 1949.

Because their bodies were not found for more than two weeks, it could not be determined whether Edna or her husband, James, died first. If one died before the other, then the surviving spouse would have inherited all of the couple’s community property, and the benefits would be paid out to that person’s beneficiaries.

I called the Odessa Public Library, and they emailed me stories about the crash, along with a copy of Edna’s obituary, which listed her survivors. Among them was her father, Fred Sherman, of Coalgate, Okla.

With a little more digging I found that Fred Sherman had been the moonshine-busting sheriff of Coal County. He also served in the Oklahoma Legislature and later worked as a railroad detective.

It wasn't hard to imagine how a pregnant 15-year-old daughter of a law-and-order sheriff in the heart of the Bible Belt might get shipped off to Arizona.

Other details seemed to help the story fall into place: Sherman had once owned a gold-and-silver plated .44 revolver that cowboy actor and showman Tom Mix greatly admired. Mix had Arizona connections (he died in a single-car crash near Florence in 1940), and several people who had sent tips to Syman after the "Unsolved Mysteries" episode aired named him as the father.

But coincidences are not proof. And the theory raised more questions.

If Edna Sherman Roe was Sharon’s mother, how did Sharon wind up in a hatbox on a remote roadway in Arizona on Christmas Eve? Was the young couple who claimed to find her after their car broke down at the exact location where someone left Sharon part of a miracle or some elaborate plot?

And given all the secrecy surrounding adoptions — it took a court order to unseal Sharon’s case in 1986 — how would Edna have seen Sharon in 1935?

◆ ◆ ◆

As I continued to trace Fred Sherman’s descendants, I found another tantalizing clue: Dorothy Wooden, the woman who had held on to Sharon’s papers, was a niece of Edna Sherman Roe.

Sharon told me she didn’t know how her mother knew Dorothy but had often commented that they looked so much alike that they could be cousins, especially because they both had red hair.

Dorothy obviously held a key, but to what?

I began trying to track her down. Her last address was in Southern California near Palm Springs, but she didn’t appear to live there anymore. I tried all the people-finder databases I could find and even enlisted friends of mine who work for newspapers in California.

Her name didn’t register in the Social Security Death Index, so I knew she was likely still alive, but she had apparently gone off the grid.

After a little more sleuthing, I tracked down another descendant of Fred Sherman who lived in Tucson. She turned out to be another niece of Edna Sherman Roe.

I called her and told her the Hatbox Baby story and asked if she could help me find Dorothy Wooden.

She said she hadn’t heard from her in years and had no idea how to reach her.

Before I hung up, however, I asked her if she might be willing to help solve the mystery.

Would she be willing to take a DNA test?

“I don’t see why not,” she said. “Especially if it would help that lady with some answers.”

I called Sharon with the news, and she was excited. After 80 years, we might finally know who her birth mother was, which might lead us to who left her in the desert and, perhaps most importantly, why.

This was before the boom in DNA self-testing kits. Conducting a test on the niece would be expensive. I called several companies, and one agreed to do it at cost.

There was one more complication. The woman in Tucson wanted to do it after the holidays.

But I was on the hook with my editors for a Christmas story, so in the finest traditions of journalism, I went with what I had and wrote the story with a cliffhanger ending.

In January, I called the woman to arrange for me to go to Tucson and collect a cheek swab.

She told me she’d had a change of heart. She didn’t want to be a part of the story, and she wouldn’t be taking any DNA test.

Sharon was crushed when I told her the news. There had been times when she said she no longer cared whether she found the answer to who she really was, but this time I had raised her hopes.

I told her I’d keep trying to find Dorothy Wooden.

◆ Chasing ghosts down rabbit holes

It would take me five years and the help of a private investigator, along with dozens of letters sent to addresses throughout California.

When Dorothy Wooden finally called me, we spoke for more than an hour.

She told me how she’d grown up poor in Oklahoma and as a young girl had spent the summer with Edna in Odessa.

She described trips to department stores and fabulous dresses and fancy dinners with china, silver and crystal. She said she remembered a young oil tycoon by the name of George H.W. Bush had been a dinner guest with the Roes, which I was unable to verify.

Dorothy knew all about the story of the Hatbox Baby, but no, she wasn’t related to Sharon, and Sharon wasn’t related to Edna Sherman Roe.

Dorothy and Faith had become friends in the 1970s when Dorothy was working as a real estate agent and had helped Faith with a home sale.

Dorothy said Faith must have “borrowed” the Edna Sherman Roe story because she thought it sounded romantic and would make Sharon feel better about being abandoned as a baby.

It appeared I had spent a lot of time chasing ghosts down rabbit holes.

But the Edna Sherman Roe episode wasn’t a total waste.

Her niece wasn’t willing to take a DNA test, but Sharon still was. And in just a few years, so would millions of other Americans.

Could one of them solve the mystery of the Hatbox Baby?

Will DNA tests unlock new clues?

On Oct. 1, 2016, I received an email from a woman in Oregon who had read my 2011 story about the Hatbox Baby.

Glenda Poling and her sisters were looking for a sibling who, according to family lore, had been taken away from their mother in, of all things, a hatbox.

I’d been down this road a number of times before and was skeptical.

The Hatbox Baby, according to sensational media reports in 1931, had been found on a remote roadside, abandoned inside a hatbox. Decades later, Sharon Elliott contacted me to tell me she had been that baby, which set off a new round of interest — and tips that couldn't be proved.

Glenda and her sisters had contacted Sharon and private investigator Alice Syman years earlier after seeing Sharon’s story on "Unsolved Mysteries," but had never followed through with a DNA test.

“Without getting into a lot of detail at this point,” Glenda wrote, “there was a circumstance in our family where a baby, my parent's firstborn, was placed in a 'pretty' box and promptly removed from the house — this happened in the early 1930's in Silver City NM.”

BABYFULSTONE MYSTERY: Sisters search forlong-lost sibling born in Silver City

Sharon had been found on Christmas Eve of 1931, stuffed into a black, pasteboard hatbox and abandoned beside a remote desert highway between Mesa and Superior.

The timing was about right, but it was the location Glenda mentioned that was intriguing.

Silver City sits in far southwestern New Mexico and would have been a long day’s drive from Mesa in 1931. It was accessible by rail and bus.

I was interested, but still unconvinced.

Glenda offered to send me pictures of her mother. Aside from hair color, she didn’t bear a great resemblance to Sharon. I told Glenda I’d stay in touch.

A month or so later, in November of 2016, another unsolved mystery made headlines in Phoenix. It had nothing to do with Sharon, but it helped propel the search for her mother in a whole new direction.

The story involved a break in a pair of grisly Phoenix murders from the early 1990s. The twist: The notorious Canal Killer had been caught with DNA evidence.

Police had used an emerging technique called forensic genealogy to arrest a man in the murders of two young women whose bodies were found in Phoenix canals in 1992 and 1993.

It was one of the first cases ever solved with the technique. Since then, police have used it increasingly to solve cold cases, such as the notorious Golden Gate killer case in Sacramento, Calif.

For one of her stories about the Canal Killer arrest, my colleague Megan Cassidy interviewed a DNA expert named Bennett Greenspan, president of a company called Family Tree DNA, one of several new technology companies that specialize in helping individuals trace their ancestry through genetic matches.

And the technology was exploding. In 2013, only 330,000 Americans had paid for personal DNA testing. By 2017, the number was nearly 5 million. Today, that number is over 12 million, with the largest segment on Ancestry.com — which has more than 7 million profiles in its database.

I called Greenspan and told him about Sharon’s case. He agreed to help.

But first, I had to ask Sharon if she was willing to try again, knowing the risk of disappointment.

◆ ◆ ◆

Sharon was nearing her 85th birthday, and it had been five years since I’d written about her case. In that story, a few years earlier, I had identified a potential relative who was willing to take a DNA test. The relative backed out after the story was published.

When I brought up the idea of giving DNA another shot, she was surprisingly game.

I met her at her tidy apartment in Mesa with photojournalist Michael Chow. Sharon had slowed down since the last time I saw her and was limping from a painfully arthritic foot, but she was her usual bright and cheerful self. She had that same lilting sing-song voice I’d heard nearly three decades earlier when she first called me looking for information about her case.

I told her I was worried about her living on the second floor with her foot in such bad shape, and she assured me she was on the waiting list for a first-floor apartment and expected one to become available soon.

We sat down at her kitchen table and opened the DNA sample kit from Family Tree. I offered to help her with the cheek swab, but she wouldn’t hear of it and insisted on doing it herself.

I boxed her sample up and mailed it that day.

I emailed Greenspan with the kit number, and though it was right before the holidays —the busiest time of year for DNA testing because so many families give the kits as gifts — he agreed to expedite the analysis.

Sharon had been expecting a story for that Christmas, but I decided to hold off and wait for the test to come back.

On January 11, the results came in. The report identified matches in what it called the 30 to 80 centimorgan range. I had no idea what that meant. I emailed Greenspan for help in interpreting the analysis.

DNA TERMS EXPLAINED: A guide to genealogy vocabulary

It turned out centimorgans measure genetic linkage. Each of us has 6,800 to 7,000, and we share roughly 3,400 to 3,500 centimorgans with each parent; 2,630 for a sibling and 1,766 for a grandparent.

Sharon’s numbers were much lower.

“The results mean that no one in our database is close, genetically, to the Hatbox Baby,” Greenspan replied.

He held out the possibility that as the number of people using Family Tree grew beyond the 1 million or so users at the time, there was a chance a match could show up in the database.

When I broke the news to Sharon, she shrugged it off.

“Nothing ventured, nothing gained, right?”

◆ Could Sharon be Baby Fulstone?

Six weeks later, Glenda contacted me again, saying she and her brother and sister had all taken DNA tests. I replied that Sharon had taken one as well, and Glenda asked if I would share the results with her.

There was a hitch: They had used Ancestry and 23andMe, while I had used Family Tree DNA. Because each service uses a proprietary database, two siblings who use different services would not find connections with each other without specialized knowledge.

Later in the day, Glenda sent me another photo. This one stopped me in my tracks.

It was a photo of Glenda’s grandmother, the woman who had taken the baby away from Glenda’s mother.

I thought the resemblance with Sharon was stunning.

I’ve never been good at seeing likenesses in peoples’ faces, even in my own family, so I sought confirmation by showing the pictures side-by-side to colleagues in the newsroom.

“Is that the same woman?” they asked.

I showed the pictures to my wife. She agreed. The resemblance was uncanny.

Glenda agreed.

“Oh my goodness John, we are stunned, they look like mother / daughter instead of grandmother / grand-daughter,” she wrote.

I told Glenda I would send her a Family Tree DNA test, and gave her the names of the all of the people involved in the Hatbox Baby story: Ed and Julia Stewart; Julia's cousins John and Betty Mansfield, even Edna Sherman Roe, so they could check them against the DNA results they already had from other services.

And though I was excited beyond words at being on the brink of finally solving the mystery of the Hatbox Baby, I avoided telling Sharon.

I’d disappointed her too many times, and even though this looked like a sure thing, I didn’t want to let her down again.

Six weeks later Glenda’s results came in.

No match.

I was glad I hadn’t told Sharon about Glenda’s case, but I felt a little guilty for letting her down again with the whole DNA experiment.

I was afraid we’d reached another in a long string of dead ends.

But I didn’t know what I didn’t know.

Another story yields unexpected help

Time was beginning to run out.

I had spent nearly 30 years off and on trying to solve the mystery of the Hatbox Baby and was not much closer than when I had started.

Who had left an infant in a hatbox beside a remote Arizona road on Christmas Eve of 1931?

I wrote my first story on the case in 1988, after Sharon Elliott had called me at the newspaper I worked for. She told me she had recently learned from her dying mother that she was the infant who was found abandoned in the desert in a hatbox between Mesa and Superior on Christmas Eve of 1931.

She had never known she was adopted.

A DNA test showed no close relatives. A second test was taken after an Oregon woman searching for a sibling sent me a photo of her grandmother that closely resembled Sharon. This time there was no match at all.

A few months after that second disappointment, I tried calling Sharon to see how she was doing. Her number had been disconnected. I drove to her apartment, and the person who answered the door said she had just moved in and didn’t know where the previous tenant had gone.

With a growing sense of dread, I knocked on a neighbor’s door and asked about Sharon.

The neighbor told me Sharon had suffered a bad fall because of her arthritic foot and had moved in with family to recuperate.

I talked to her guardian, the husband of Sharon’s granddaughter. He told me she was living with his family for the time being and would be moving to an acute care home not far from her old apartment.

He was hopeful rehabilitation treatment would help her back on her feet.

But reading between the lines, he didn’t seem optimistic.

I began to worry that I wouldn’t be able to help Sharon find the answers she’d been seeking for so many years.

I thought back on the stories I’d written and wish I’d done things differently.

I wish I’d have asked more questions of Joe B. Maier, the constable who led the investigation the night Sharon was found. Had he kept a diary or ever filed police reports in the case? I knew Maier long before I ever heard of the Hatbox Baby. He was my neighbor when I was a cub reporter at the Mesa Tribune and living in downtown Mesa.

I regretted not doing a follow-up story after the "Unsolved Mysteries" episode. I regretted not trying harder to track down Ed and Julia Stewart, the couple who found the Hatbox Baby, while they were still alive.

I wish I’d have tried again to reach Betty Mansfield, Julia Stewart’s cousin, after her husband hung up on me.

But opportunities lost are just that, and with each passing day, the chances of finding someone who had firsthand knowledge of Sharon’s case were dwindling.

◆ John D'Anna appears on stage

In July 2017, I was asked to appear on stage as part of at The Arizona Republic’s Arizona Storytellers project, which features individuals from the community telling personal stories in front of a live audience.

The theme for the project's sixth anniversary was “stories about stories,” and I was to appear with five of my colleagues to showcase the craft of journalism by telling a true story about something memorable from our careers.

I had just been involved in a fairly significant press-freedom legal case involving stories I’d written about the murder of a priest and the attempted murder of his associate, and I’m pretty sure that was the story my bosses expected me to tell.

But as the night of the program approached, I decided I’d tell the story of the Hatbox Baby instead. In 35 years practicing journalism, I’ve written thousands of stories and edited probably 10 times that. I’ve been a member of two teams that were finalists for the Pulitzer Prize in breaking news and played a role in "The Wall" project that won the Pulitzer this year.

But out of all those stories, I can’t think of one that has stuck with me as much as Sharon Elliott’s.

When I first wrote about Sharon in 1988, I felt pretty good that I had played a role in solving the mystery of whatever became of the Hatbox Baby.

Longtime Republic columnist Don Dedera actually congratulated me and told me that he’d wanted to be the one to find Sharon ever since he first wrote a story on the 30th anniversary of the case in 1961 — the year after I was born.

And it definitely stoked my ego to see a story I had written become an "Unsolved Mysteries" episode. (If you happen to catch it on Hulu or the Lifetime Network, they actually pan over the story with my byline on it.)

But as the years passed, I grew to realize that my story had only solved part of the mystery of the Hatbox Baby.

Even after private investigator Alice Syman got involved, and after thousands of tips poured in to "Unsolved Mysteries," Sharon still didn’t know who had abandoned her in the desert or why.

I began to see Sharon in a different light as well.

She was still the same person with the sunny disposition and the twinkle in her blue eyes whom I'd met in 1988, but she was also someone with a hole in her life.

She first learned she was adopted at age 55, shortly before the only woman she knew as mother died. The knowledge, in essence, robbed her of blood relatives she thought she’d had in her life. The family lore of her mother, and her mother’s parents and sister, no longer belonged to her.

The only blood relatives she had now were her daughter, and her daughter’s children and grandchildren. What lore could she pass on to them?

Over the years, I assigned several reporters to do updates on the Hatbox Baby and I wrote several myself.

Sharon wanted answers, but there were times when she worried what those answers might be, something most adoptees understand.

Sharon relished the romantic theory that she was perhaps the love child of a movie star’s illicit affair. But what if there was some awful story behind her birth? What if she was the product of a criminal act or some unspeakable shame? Wouldn’t she be better off not knowing?

When Sharon was in her 70s, I wrote a story about how she had accepted the fact that she might never know the answer and was comfortable just being a mother and grandmother. But when she was in her 80s, she had decided that she really did want to know the answers, regardless of what they were. So willing in fact, that she gamely agreed to take a DNA test.

Every story I wrote or assigned carried with it the hope that it would jog a memory or yield a clue that would help solve the rest of the mystery.

And so when my turn came to take the stage on that Arizona Storytellers night in July 2017, I began to tell the audience of 300 the story of how Sharon had called me one day out of the blue on the city desk and asked if I could help her find information about the “Hatbox Baby.”

I talked about how she was hailed nationwide as a Christmas miracle when she was found in that hatbox on the road from Superior to Mesa by a couple who just happened to have car trouble on Christmas Eve.

I talked about how that couple, Ed and Julia Stewart, never even told their own children they’d found a baby and how upset they were when "Unsolved Mysteries" aired an episode based on my story. They maintained until their dying days that they just found the baby, and they resented any implication that they were part of some kind of ruse to help an unwed mother.

I talked about the woman in Oregon as well as another tantalizing clue, a note written in Sharon’s mother’s hand suggesting that her birth mother was an heiress who later died in a plane crash. Both were false starts. I mentioned how the DNA test yielded no close relatives.

I closed by saying that Sharon was not doing well, that she had fallen and broken a hip. I said that I wanted to solve the mystery for her but was worried that time would run out before I could.

I talked about how she was one of the sweetest people I knew, and I said that while journalists aren’t supposed to become a part of the stories they cover, Sharon’s story had become a part of me.

At the end of the show, as the storytellers mingled with the audience, a woman approached me. She challenged my assertion that the DNA test had proved fruitless. In fact, she said, DNA always provides clues, but sometimes you just have to know how to interpret them.

“I’m Bonnie,” she said. “I’m an amateur DNA genealogist. Maybe I can help.”

A genealogy detective on the case

When Bonnie Belza goes out to dinner with friends and the question comes up, she explains DNA by picking up the salt and pepper shakers. Each one represents a parent.

She sprinkles some of each into a single pile. That’s you, she'll say, a half-salt and half-pepper mix from each parent.

Then she opens up a sugar packet. That’s your spouse, who will be a half-and-half mix of whatever his or her parents are.

And if you have kids, their DNA will be half sugar and half salt and pepper.

It’s a simple visual to help explain a complicated subject, but it’s a subject Belza is passionate about because it pairs so well with one of her other passions: genealogy. And her two passions helped her make more progress in a year and a half than I'd made in 30 years of trying to solve the mystery of the Hatbox Baby.

Belza was in the audience when I laid out the mystery at an Arizona Storytellers event in July 2017.

I recounted the story of a tiny, red-haired newborn who was found in the desert stuffed into a hatbox on Christmas Eve of 1931. I described my attempts over 30 years to help Sharon Elliott find out who abandoned her and why. In that story, I mentioned that several of our attempts to solve the mystery through DNA testing had failed.

Bonnie approached me after the show, introduced herself as an amateur DNA genealogist and offered to help.

We met for coffee a few days later, and, with Sharon’s permission, I gave Bonnie the passwords to Sharon’s Family Tree DNA account.

At that point, I began to learn how much I didn’t know.

In the course of my DNA education, I would interview Richard Hill, a scientist and an adoptee who wrote a gripping memoir about how he became one of the first people to track down his birth parents with DNA.

I would also talk with Paul Fronczak, author of "The Foundling," the true story of a baby who was kidnapped from a Chicago maternity ward in 1964. Two years later, an abandoned baby was found in New Jersey and, after some questionable police work and pressure from the media, the toddler was identified as the kidnapped baby and reunited with the Fronczak family.

As a boy, Fronczak learned of the kidnapping by accident. He had never felt like he fit in with his family, and he always wondered if he really was the baby who had been kidnapped.

DNA testing proved he wasn’t. That wrought a cascade of anger and grief from his parents and opened two other doors: He learned he had a twin sister who has never been found and may have been murdered. And he renewed the mystery of what became of the real Paul Fronczak, who has never been found.

Both Hill and Fronczak agreed the Hatbox Baby case deserved to be solved and offered to help in any way they could. But for the moment, Bonnie was my tutor, and she started with the basics in Sharon Elliot’s case.

◆ ◆ ◆

Six months before I told Sharon’s story in front of a live audience, I’d had her take a Family Tree DNA test, which came back with what I believed were disappointing results.

When Bonnie first approached me, she told me that DNA never fails to yield clues. You just have to know how to interpret them.

Later, as we embarked together on a year and a half long journey into Sharon’s ancestry, Bonnie pointed out that we had used the service Family Tree.

She suggested we also have Sharon take tests with Ancestry.com and 23andMe, which would lead to more chances of finding a match.

Belza has been down this road before. She’s been interested in genealogy since the 1980s and used it to solve a family mystery about a relative who had disappeared in the early 1900s. She also wanted to learn as much about her family tree as she could for health reasons: Her father had developed retinitis pigmentosa, a genetic eye disease that eventually caused him to go blind.

Bonnie had set out on a different path. She started out as a home economics major at Arizona State University, with the intent of becoming a stewardess, which is what flight attendants were called in those days. But she got engaged, which necessitated a change in career paths because, at the time, the airlines required flight attendants to be single.

So she switched her major to business, which, with engineering, were the only options for anyone who wanted to study computer science.

In college, she began working for American Express, handling card services and reservations, which used to be done over the phone. She eventually became a collections agent, which required her to use the technique of skip tracing to track down people with delinquent accounts, measures that appealed to her inner snoop.

She rose through the ranks at American Express, helping usher the company into the computer age. All the while, she was using her newfound skills to try the nascent versions of genealogy software.

DNA TEST KITS: Five things to know before you take one yourself

When she retired in 2015, one of the items on her bucket list was to take a cruise through the Panama Canal. A friend told her about a specialty canal cruise for genealogy enthusiasts that featured three of the biggest names in the field: Blaine Bettinger; CeCe Moore, a consultant for the popular television show Finding Your Roots; and Angie Bush, who has degrees in microbiology and biotechnology and is a professional genetic genealogist. Bonnie signed up immediately.

She was hooked. She never even put on her bathing suit or got in the pool. Instead, she spent almost all of her time at seminars, drinking in as much as she could.

When she got back from the cruise, she wasted no time hitting up every relative over age 75 to take DNA tests. It was important to get them while they were still around.

Since then she's attended as many genealogy and DNA conferences and workshops as she could to further her knowledge.

◆ A 5,000 piece jigsaw puzzle

When I met her, she was sharing that knowledge by teaching a continuing education class called DNA Kindergarten, where she walked people through the basics.

She had also used her skills more than half a dozen times to help friends and acquaintances — and sometimes even strangers — solve family mysteries.

She likens each challenge to solving a 5,000-piece jigsaw puzzle in which every piece is exactly the same size, shape and color — on both sides.

It’s a challenge she has loved. The precision and structure of the family tree appeal to the computer programmer side of her, and the methodical detective work required provides the thrill of the hunt. There’s also the satisfaction that comes with solving a mystery, even though there is seldom a neatly tied ending, and more often the solution is news the subject of the mystery doesn’t want to hear.

She tells everyone up front that DNA detective work may unlock deeply uncomfortable secrets that some would rather stay buried. At best, those secrets can provide a measure of comfort to those who long to find out who they are and where they came from. At worst, those secrets can destroy venerated images of ancestors, rewrite cherished kinship lore and fracture families.

Her research into the Hatbox Baby case would be no different. Secrets would be exposed along with troubling truths about virtually every family involved in the case, from the people who found her to the people whose DNA connects them to Sharon in ways they are not comfortable with.

Bonnie’s 5,000-piece jigsaw puzzle would build out to half a dozen interlocking trees and a database with more than 4,500 names connected to Sharon's case. And as with any puzzle, the best way to start building it is around the edges.

◆ Tracing back the family tree

The first step in solving any genealogical relationship mystery is to find the most recent common ancestors, then follow those branches of the family tree to see if they intersect with other branches.

One of the ways DNA family linkage is expressed is by “shared centimorgans.” Centimorgans measure genetic linkage. Each of us has 6,800 to 7,000, and we share roughly 3,400 to 3,500 centimorgans with each parent; 2,630 for a sibling and 1,766 for a grandparent.

In Sharon’s first DNA test, her strongest connections showed 30 to 80 shared centimorgans, indicating third or fourth cousins at best.

Third cousins are the great-grandchildren of a great-great-aunt or great-great uncle. A single set of great-great grandparents links them. Fourth cousins share a set of great-great-great grandparents.

Using genealogy software, along with thousands of family trees posted publicly on online sites like Ancestry.com, Bonnie painstakingly began to trace the highest centimorgan relatives back, generation by generation, to find their most recent common ancestors.

After several months, she felt certain that Sharon’s ancestors had descended from German immigrants who initially settled in eastern Iowa in the 1850s, just a few years after Iowa became a state and was eagerly seeking new residents with promises of rich farm soil and the opportunity to own land.

A handful of family names started to emerge. If she could find where those branches intersected, she would have the trunk of the tree: the Hatbox Baby’s birth parents.

As Bonnie began to log the potential third and fourth cousins identified in Sharon’s DNA profile, she checked them against family trees that were posted publicly online at sites like Ancestry.com.

Each one would become a branch of Sharon's family tree, and eventually would help identify what genealogists call the MRCA, or most recent common ancestor, which is the key to solving virtually every genealogical mystery.

In Sharon’s case, many of the distant cousins that showed up in her DNA database all seemed to have roots within a 30-mile radius of Davenport, Iowa, mostly from small farm communities along the Mississippi River with names like Lowden, Wheatland, Buffalo and Blue Grass.

For Bonnie, that presented both a good and a bad problem. On one hand, relatives concentrated in one place might make it easier to find a most recent common ancestor. On the other, tight-knit clans tend to intermarry, which is known in genealogical terms as endogamy and can result in a family tree whose branches are hopelessly tangled.

In endogamous communities, it’s not unusual to find two brothers who marry two sisters, which would produce two sets of offspring with very similar DNA.There can be other relationships, such as when a father and son marry two sisters, or when second cousins marry, which is legal in the U.S.

Sharon’s family tree was similarly complicated.

◆ Crowdsourced DNA could crack the case

Luckily, genealogy has exploded as a passion among the American public. The number of people who have taken home DNA tests will likely eclipse 15 million by the end of this holiday season.

In addition, millions of people willingly post their family trees online, submit them to local libraries and circulate them to relatives. Current genealogical computer programs also allow data to be downloaded into Excel files, allowing users to build pivot tables and filter for common threads.

Using public family trees and the computer skills she honed in her long career at American Express, Bonnie painstakingly traced each potential relative, combing public records for confirmation and searching Newspapers.com to see if any of them ever made headlines.

After several months she had built out a family tree so large it could no longer be viewed in its entirety on one computer screen. She went old-school and hung a 12-foot roll of newsprint in the hallway of her Scottsdale home. An index card carried each name, along with dates of birth and death.

Some of the cards contained a single question mark.

For Bonnie, Sharon’s case had become a passion, but it was also a labor of love. She feels incredible empathy for adoptees who long to know where they came from, and this was particularly so in Sharon’s case.

It must be so hard, she often said, when the only flesh-and-blood relative you really know is your own child.

Bonnie wanted to make sure Sharon understood the research she was doing. She sat with Sharon for several hours one day and explained how DNA works, but instead of using salt, pepper and sugar, she illustrated the concept with the brightly colored beads that she uses in her DNA Kindergarten class.

And she kept up with her research. By November 2017, she had a list of surnames that had strong possibilities. First among them: Strackbein. Other strong contenders were Kautz and Roth.

By early December, Bonnie had found the one place where those names intersected. The trunk of Sharon's family tree.

Was a decades-old mystery about to be solved?

Her mother died when she was three months old, and her father, with six older children, could not care for a seventh. Her uncle, so the family story goes, took the train to a funeral one day and came home with a baby.

By the time she was 12, she would be orphaned again and left to the care of older cousins who lived in a 19th-century farmhouse 30 miles north of Davenport, Iowa.

A few years later, she would be working as a servant for a well-to-do family who lived in a mansion on a hill overlooking the Mississippi River.

As one relative put it, she felt her family turned her back on her, so she turned her back on the family.

We don’t know how she met the man she would marry.

We do know that she was the mother of Sharon Elliott, the Arizona woman known as the Hatbox Baby, and she was nearly five months pregnant when she married.

The man she married came from Iowa farm stock as well, growing up near the towns of Buffalo and Blue Grass, about 15 miles west of Davenport.

His mother, prim and proper, came from a well-to-do family that owned a prosperous lumber business. His father owned a large farm in the rich bottom land along the Mississippi, and together the men in the family ran a threshing business, helping other farm families at harvest time.

And we know that he was Sharon's father.

◆ A family history finally revealed

DNA genealogist Bonnie Belza had been closing in on the mystery for weeks.

She had isolated several distinct family lines in Sharon's DNA. For 30 years, we had searched for this connection in an attempt to solve the mystery of the baby found abandoned in a hatbox in the Arizona desert on Christmas Eve of 1931.

Those family lines, Strackbein, Roth, and Kautz, belonged to German immigrants who had settled near Davenport in the 1850s.

They came from Wonderthausen, a town in the North Rhine-Westphalia region about 75 miles from Dusseldorf, with a history that dates to the early 1300s.

Under Prussian rule in the 1800s, the region had transformed from a feudal society in which peasants were not allowed to own land to a more egalitarian system. But inheritance rules favored the oldest children, meaning there was little opportunity for younger siblings to own land. The winters were harsh, taxation was high, and military service was compulsory.

As transatlantic transportation improved, hundreds took the opportunity to emigrate. Among them were members of the Strackbein family, who settled in and around the town of Wheatland, Iowa, and nearby Lowden.

On Dec. 19, two days after Sharon's 86th birthday, Bonnie emailed me.

“The couple - that are possibly the parents of Sharon are Freda Strackbein (b 1908 d 1991) and Walter Kautz Roth (b 1909 d 2005),” she said.

Freda Strackbein and Walter Kautz Roth.

For the first time since I began writing about Sharon Elliott’s quest to find who abandoned her as an infant in the desert, there was a plausible theory, one that was based on science and evidence-based reasoning.

Bonnie told me that Walter and Freda had married on Aug. 1, 1931 — four and a half months before Sharon Elliott was born — and that they had another child who was born in 1933.

If Bonnie was right, that meant Sharon had a brother she never knew.

It also meant a whole new layer of complexity to the Hatbox Baby mystery: Why would a married couple give up their baby, even if it had been conceived out of wedlock, and how did that baby get from Iowa to the Arizona desert?

Bonnie had traced both Walter and Freda’s family trees extensively and was confident she had the right couple. But there still could be other possibilities. What if Walter’s brother had been the father? That would produce roughly the same DNA match.

I was excited by Bonnie’s news, but I had to be cautious about what I shared with Sharon. The first time I’d brought up DNA testing in 2011 turned into a crushing disappointment for her, and I’d seen enough dead ends to know this, as promising as it looked, could be another one.

I decided I would tell her that Bonnie had isolated several family lines and describe the German and eastern Iowa connections without naming Walter and Freda.

I drove out to the sprawling care home in East Mesa where Sharon was trying without much luck to rehab her broken hip. In all the years I knew her, I never heard Sharon utter a cross word, but I know she didn’t think much of the food there. Whenever I visited I always asked if I could bring her anything next time. The answer was usually “snacks.”

Chester’s Puffcorn was her favorite, and I brought two bags with me, along with some Hershey’s kisses for her sweet tooth.

But when I got there, Sharon wasn’t there, and because I wasn’t a direct family member, the staff couldn’t tell me where she’d gone.

I called Sharon’s granddaughter, who told me Sharon had taken a turn for the worse and was in the intensive care unit.

I drove to Banner Baywood and found her room. The nurses said it was OK for her to have a visitor. I found her sitting up picking at her hospital food.

She said she was on the mend and would be out in a couple of days.

I decided to stick with my plan and describe what Bonnie had found in general terms.

“You’ve been busy,” Sharon said.

But Bonnie had been busier.

She’d combed Newspapers.com and not only found Walter and Freda’s obituaries, but also their wedding announcement, which noted that for their honeymoon, the couple planned to take “an extended trip to Sioux City and points west.”

Did points west mean Arizona?

Bonnie also found an obituary for their son.

James Evan Roth, perhaps the brother Sharon never knew, had just died two weeks earlier.

◆ ◆ ◆

I decided to wait until after the holidays to contact his family.

When I did, I told the woman on the phone who I was and a little bit about Sharon’s case.

Then I told her it was very likely that James had a sibling he never knew about.

She told me it was a lot to take in and asked me to write everything down in an email.

I called her a week later. She seemed perplexed about how DNA could identify Walter and Freda as the parents if neither they nor their son had taken a DNA test. I tried to explain, and then told her she could settle the question — and provide the answers Sharon had been seeking for 30 years — if she would take a DNA test. I told her I would pay for it.

She said it was out of the question.

It wasn’t the answer I had been expecting.

When I asked why, she told me that if her ancestors had gone to their graves with a secret, it wasn’t her place to expose it.

I would drive out to California twice to try to convince her to change her mind, but with no luck.

If we were to prove Walter and Freda were definitely Sharon Elliott’s birth parents, we would need to do it without their son’s family.

We would need a lucky break.

It would come four months later.

DNA tests are not static snapshots in time. When you submit your saliva sample, the results become part of the database of whatever company you’ve chosen to go with. As more people take tests, their results are added to the database.

In April of 2018, a new match showed up in Sharon’s DNA profile. It was a strong connection, in the first-cousin range.

Bonnie reached out. The connection turned out to be a 39-year-old woman who lived near Davenport, Iowa.

Her name was Emily Dodds Farro. She was married, had two children, and owned a small business with her husband, who is a U.S. Army veteran.

And she was an adoptee looking for her birth parents.

Emily’s DNA not only tied her directly to Sharon, but also to Walter and Freda Roth. And it connected them all in a way that confirmed that Walter and Freda were Sharon’s birth parents.

Even though Bonnie had isolated Sharon’s most likely birth parents months earlier, I had avoided giving Sharon the details because I wanted to be sure, and though we had the who, we still didn’t have the how or why the Hatbox Baby got from Iowa to the middle of the Arizona desert.

But after Emily’s DNA profile surfaced, providing concrete proof that Sharon was the daughter of Walter Kautz Roth and Freda Strackbein Roth, I decided to lay it out for Sharon. I told her everything I knew about Walter and Freda and their son James, the brother Sharon never knew she had.

I even showed her pictures.

She showed no reaction at all.

I asked her about it on my next visit.

She said she’d given the pictures and the family tree information to her great-grandson, Erik Clark, to take care of.

I asked her if the reason she didn’t feel a connection was because those were the people who didn’t want her.

She smiled and shrugged and said, “Could be.”

It was clearly a lot to take in. When I finally told her about Emily, she was thrilled and began referring to Emily as her niece.

Even if that was the only thing that came out of our 30-year search, it would have been enough.

◆ Another adopted child gets answers

When you send in your DNA sample, you open yourself up to certain risks, and one of those is learning things you would rather not have known. Sharon willingly took that risk. She knew her birth parents could have been poor or criminals or that she could have been conceived in scandal or shame.

As a journalist writing about other people’s DNA tests, I began to learn that I would also face similar risks. People who had willingly made their results public in their own quests for answers had put me in the position of having information that others would rather I did not have.

From Emily’s DNA profile, Bonnie was able to find Emily's branch in the family tree and identify her birth mother — a relative of James Roth.

I was caught in the middle. If I tried to pursue the relative with this new information, it could jeopardize any chance Emily had of trying to connect with her birth mother. But Emily could also jeopardize any chance I had of getting this person to help me paint the picture of Walter and Freda and find out how and why Sharon wound up in the desert on Christmas Eve of 1931.

I decided to step back and see how things with Emily and her birth mother played out.

It did not go well.

She reached out several times by phone and by mail. She sent a letter with pictures of her children and a description of her life in Iowa.

It was returned. She sent a certified letter. In it, she thanked her birth mother for giving her the gift of life. She told her she had been blessed with a wonderful adoptive family (who supported her in her search), along with a loving husband, two terrific children, and a successful business.

That too was returned.

With that, Emily decided she would respect her birth mother’s wishes to be left alone.

While her attempts to contact her birth mother were disappointing, Emily was delighted to learn she was related to Sharon and sent her a card with photos of her children.

In November, I told Sharon I would be going to Iowa at the end of the month to find out more about Walter and Freda. She was more interested in whether I was going to see Emily.

I told her I would.

In the meantime, I wanted to do as much research as I could in advance so I could make the most of my trip.

The quest to solve the mystery of the Hatbox Baby is one filled with remarkable coincidences. I just happened to pick up the phone when Sharon called. DNA genealogist Bonnie Belza just happened to be in the audience when I told Sharon’s story. Emily Farro just happened to be looking for her birth mother and provided the link that would prove Sharon’s birth parents.

But none of those coincidences were as random or bizarre as one that would occur before I left for Iowa.

◆ ◆ ◆

After an early morning fitness class, I ran into a fellow class member at the Starbucks across the parking lot. We talked a bit about our jobs, and I mentioned a couple of stories I’d written along with the one I was currently working on — the Hatbox Baby.
