search_result.title: Delaware State gives next steps for campus security after protest
search_result.text:
They shut down a campus street for hours. Hundreds surrounded the public safety building to protest against university police and the handling of sexual assault cases. They packed an entire auditorium for a town hall meeting that stretched nearly nine hours long.

This week, students demanded to feel safe on their Delaware State University campus. Now, they're starting to see the next steps from their school.

"Your bravery and strength are clear and compelling," said President Tony Allen in a statement Friday evening, following the town hall that ended around 3 a.m. the same day. "Now is an opportunity for us to support you better and with the care and compassion you should expect."

Allen outlined what he stressed to be "initial steps" for the Dover institution. These measures join the president's previously shared plan to pair university experts with a student coalition, the counseling center, police and the Title IX office to create “sexual assault awareness activities and interventions” on campus.

Some new steps

Assigning Deputy Chief Joi Simmons as the university's “ Sexual Assault Awareness officer .” Allen noted she has extensive training in sexual assault education, investigations and survivor services.

.” Allen noted she has extensive training in sexual assault education, investigations and survivor services. Upgrading security to include lighting throughout the main campus and DSU Downtown — including the emergency blue lights system .

— including the . Ensuring that the existing public safety escort service is “fulfilling the needs of students.”

Enhancing camera use on campus and in the residence halls . Allen did not specify further where these cameras would be located.

. Allen did not specify further where these cameras would be located. Extending counseling hours to Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m., and Saturday, 9 a.m. to noon, through the end of February — at which point Allen says DSU will reassess its regular hours. Additionally, virtual health services are available . This will join special support groups for students who are survivors or allies, he said.

. This will join special support groups for students who are survivors or allies, he said. Allen also plans to convene the first in a series of “mandatory sensitivity trainings” for the entire university community throughout the remainder of this semester.

More:Delaware State responds to protest cries with town hall meeting — but closed it to public

Still growing:Colleges are shrinking. But HBCUs like Delaware State are riding a wave of their own

Why were Delaware State students protesting?

Calls without answers, long times spent waiting for response, avoiding stairwells, fear of walking alone at night — students had a lot to say about campus safety. And they found a megaphone to do it.

Hundreds of students protested in Dover on Wednesday afternoon, Jan. 18, calling for change within the Delaware State University Police Department. The protest pushed into the late afternoon.

Students called for better response times, better training and more transparent handling of sexual assault cases by the Delaware State University Police Department. Several said they do not feel safe on campus. Others fear more sexual assaults are going unreported because they say they are not taken seriously.

Background:Delaware State students protest for more action, better response from university police

The university responded with a town hall meeting, set for 6 p.m. the next evening in the Education and Humanities Theatre. Media was barred from attending. Parents also told Delaware Online they were unable to attend.

The meeting would end up stretching nearly nine hours in the night, several students said Friday. Ending by about 3 a.m., the packed house heard emotional testimony, firsthand accounts and cries that the meeting be a first step to more action.

The university community now absorbs some early steps in what their president deemed a long-term effort.

"I want to emphasize that these are initial steps, aimed at immediately improving our current practices," he wrote Friday evening. "We will work closely with the coalition as we build out our long-term plan."

search_result.title: DSU made students sign NDAs to work on new coalition for campus ...
search_result.text:
Delaware State University made anyone who wished to join its new Safe Space Coalition sign a confidentiality agreement first.

More than 100 students, parents, community members and employees form this coalition, according to the university.

This comes as university response continues to unfold in addressing recent student unrest concerning campus safety and the handling of sexual assault cases.

They crowded a table in the bustling student center, just days after a late-January protest. Comparing notes, swapping stories, drafting demands in hushed tones, their words steeped in an already restless campus atmosphere.

They had heard of a coalition forming to address concerns of safety and the handling of sexual assault cases. They heard students might get to lead it. Quickly, they agreed on their worst fear.

“I don't want it to fizzle out,” Jayda Tate said to the group, heads nodding around her. “We don't have the luxury of time at Delaware State.”

Hundreds already filed out of class, finding megaphones to speak out about feeling unsafe or not taken seriously when reporting assaults. Protesters made noise in Dover that would lead to community meetings, news coverage and discussion during a state budget hearing for the public, land-grant university.

Now, students feel that very catalyst has been muzzled.

Delaware State University made any student who wished to join the Safe Space Coalition, through the core membership or nine steering committees, sign a confidentiality agreement. It would strip over 100 members serving across these committees of free speech on these issues, if they hoped to serve on the new workgroup formed to assess campus safety and existing protocol.

Broad strokes in the agreement bar its signer from sharing “any and all information related to my participation as a committee member,” according to a copy obtained by Delaware Online/The News Journal, for fear that “such willful and unauthorized disclosure violates university policy (and) will be grounds for adverse action.”

Students stopped answering text messages. Some told this reporter they fear their school could sue them. Others fear pulled scholarships. Most didn’t have time to question the validity in their alarm.

What's the 'Safe Space Project?'What a $300K grant for Delaware State University aims to address after student protests

Background from Dover:Delaware State students are fighting for campus safety. So what's next?

A university spokesperson confirmed these agreements were sent across all members of the new coalition. The chief reason given was the possible handling of sensitive information.

"We need everybody to be on the same page and respect the privacy and confidentiality of what we're doing," said Carlos Holmes, director of news services. "Once the committees come to decisions with respect to actions that will be taken, or measures that will be implemented, then that will be shared with the campus community."

Attorney Alex Morey said she’s never heard anything quite like it.

“It's another level of troubling that they would have students purport to sign away their rights — their expressive rights under the First Amendment — to talk about these issues that are going on, that are clearly of major public concern,” said the director of Campus Rights Advocacy for the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, or FIRE.

Students have strong rights to speech at public universities, Morey explained, particularly on issues of political and public concern.

“What Delaware State is doing here is really putting these students in an incredibly difficult position,” she said. “Because they're saying we'll let you help us work to use government resources to fix this incredibly important problem — but you can't talk about it.”

The lid has been on tight in Dover. Delaware State escorted media out of the large town-hall meeting following Jan. 18 protest, while follow-up meetings were also made closed to the public. This marked the second time reporters have been removed from campus recently while trying to cover issues at the institution, including a shooting in September 2022. Several students also said these confidentiality agreements are common for student leaders, such as heads of Student Government Association, but Holmes did not offer confirmation.

Closed to public:Delaware State responds to protest cries with closed-door town hall meeting

Morey cautioned that a “well-meaning” administrator may have tied this privacy notion to discussion of sexual assault, but the public institution “is an arm of the state, using government resources" and the best practice is transparency.

Confidentiality or anonymity could have been specifically attributed perhaps to any sensitive student information, she said, if any student committee was going to be granted such access.

Anyone participating had to sign. More than 100 students, parents, community members and employees form this coalition, according to a university announcement. The “core” of appointed leaders marries nine separate steering committees that students were free to join:

Campus Health

Counseling and Prevention

Communications and Customer Service

Employee Awareness and Safety, Facility and Management

Judicial Affairs and Title IX

Project Resources and Funding

Public Safety and Student Awareness

Engagement, and Safety

One student said she wasn't surprised.

“If we can’t be open and honest about what we’re doing, what’s the point?” posed Dynah Mosley, a junior who didn’t join any committees, having expected a document like this one. She stood for hours in protest. She spoke in multiple town halls. She shared her own story as a survivor.

But the junior said she’s tired of a culture that keeps quiet.

“One of the big topics that I really tried to push for during the town hall was being open and honest,” she said. “If you want this to be a ‘family,’ then you have to be honest with your family. If you want us to trust, you have to build that trust with your family.”

It’s been nearly two months since the protest.

Quiet, 'early days’ in Delaware State response

Another student asked to remain anonymous.

Connecting on the phone over spring break, the Dover scholar’s caution remained that simply sharing whether they joined certain committees breaches the signed agreement. Even while personally more comfortable behind the scenes, they can sense its impact.

“It dilutes the very catalysts of creating that change,” the member said of student NDAs. “So it’s interesting.”

Their committees have had just one introductory meeting so far, this student said, though they hope it’s "still early days.” It is frustrating, however, having fellow Delaware State classmates unable to see much from the outside, save noticing electricians working on blue-light systems.

It’s almost dulling the pain, they said.

“It kind of dulls the very reason people became angry — about administration, faculty not handling these cases in the timely order they should be handled,” the student said of sexual assaults. “If you’re asking what the school culture or environment is right now amongst peers. ... It’s kind of been complacent.”

But this student wants to see more. And ACLU-DE would agree.

'Something's happening to my child':One survivor's family says it knows public safety culture at Delaware State, firsthand

Executive Director Mike Brickner said the organization has been trying to keep a pulse on campus unrest since the start of the year. He found news of the NDAs striking.

"Not every single student at Delaware State University is going to be able to participate. Not every single person who lives in the area of DSU is going to be able to participate. Not all of the parents or family members of people who go to DSU are going to be able to participate," Brickner said. "So this is a vent that has essentially cut off that pipeline of public information."

The director since 2020 said if this measure were intended to protect the possible disclosure of sensitive information, it's "using a sledgehammer to swat a fly."

As his organization continues to watch the university's response, he added, "It absolutely concerns us."

Holding hope for a Safe Space

President Tony Allen began pitching the scaffolding of his university response by Jan. 20. Even in what the top administrator called "initial steps," it became clear the coalition would mark central supports. The new workgroup began to form before month’s end, under a prescribed mission to assess protocol and make recommendations to his office.

Allen said the coalition is now tasked with “regular reporting” to the broader university community at least monthly.

One of the largest announcements yet came last week, to the tune of $300,000.

The historically Black university’s coalition was awarded a two-year grant to assist in developing its sexual assault response and prevention program. The "Safe Space Project” will be housed on DSU Downtown, Delaware State announced March 6. The university also committed to continuing its funding after these two years.

Like several measures Allen announced, it joins promises to upgrade campus lighting and cameras, update the blue lights system, garner body cameras for university police and assess existing escort services and counseling hours. Allen did not give an exact timeline for the efforts.

Letter from the president:'It isn't what we say or think that defines us, but what we do' (Opinion)

“I want to emphasize that these are initial steps aimed at immediately improving our current practices,” Allen wrote in a February column. “We will work closely with the coalition and committees as we build out our long-term plan.”

Sexual violence isn't unique to Delaware State, but the school saw 10 rapes reported in 2022, four other reports in January alone, and another from a parent Feb. 7. One family recently spoke out about feeling no support when her daughter reported an assault, echoing student protest concerns.

Crime statistics at neighboring University of Delaware show five assaults in 2021, with Temple University recording seven that year. These schools are nearly four times and six times larger than Delaware State in total student population, respectively.

Student organizers have repeatedly called on their school to “fortify the integrity” of its Title IX process — increasing trust and transparency, while treating cases as time-sensitive — as well as boost security, escort service, counselors for students and facility improvements to building security and water.

The Dover institution insists it's on a road to change, while experts question certain methods to get there.

For students, it’s just hard to ignore the clock.

“Delaware State University stalls these types of issues, suffocates them like a flame almost,” said the anonymous student, noting many seniors form the core coalition. “And once you graduate, that’s basically your exit ticket from the university’s issues.”

Kelly Powers covers race, culture and equity for the USA TODAY Network's Northeast Region and Delaware Online, with a focus on education. Contact her at kepowers@gannett.com or (231) 622-2191, and follow her on Twitter @kpowers01.

search_result.title: Bond named NCCo's first black police chief
search_result.text:
Xerxes Wilson

The News Journal

Lt. Col. Vaughn Bond Jr. has been named New Castle County Police Chief, making him the first African American to hold the post.

"I want to make it clear: I am very excited for the opportunity to lead such an outstanding police department," Bond said.

Bond, who had been serving as interim chief since the departure of former Chief Col. Elmer Setting in December, was named as department's head at a press conference Tuesday morning.

Choking back tears, Bond thanked a litany of family, rank and file officers and department officials including Setting and former County Executive Thomas P. Gordon for the knowledge that propelled him to chief.

"I am surrounded by the most innovative and talented minds in law enforcement today," Bond said.

The position is budgeted for a $150,000 annual salary and oversees the state's largest local police force with 400 sworn officers.

Bond began his career with New Castle County Police in December 1991 following graduation from Delaware State University. Last year, he was promoted to lieutenant colonel, the second-highest rank an officer can achieve in the New Castle County Police Department and the highest rank ever held by an African-American officer in the department’s 203-year history.

​STORY: Serial kidnapper thwarted by woman's quick thinking

STORY: Serial kidnapper strikes a third time, NCCo police say

"I have been here 26 years and I was telling the police academy the other day that I really feel like I've only been here a couple of years," Bond said. "I just enjoy the job."

County Executive Matt Meyer, who took office in January, said he initially intended to hire a firm to conduct a national search for a new chief, but decided against that upon conversations with potential search groups.

"One by one, when we gave them an overview of the department, they advised us what my intuition had become, that the talent to lead the department was within the department," Meyer said.

Our task was to find the finest person we could to move this department forward ... We have done that."

At Tuesday's event, Bond emphasized the department's responsibility in training officers to peacefully deal with those suffering from mental illness. He also reaffirmed the department's work to help, instead of punish, those addicted to heroin.

"While we are doing this, we will not forget that we are tasked with identifying those individuals who are responsible for the distribution of those illegal substances in our communities," Bond said.

He said the department must fight the distrust minority communities feel toward the police.

"It is our job to break down this barrier to make people understand we are not here to be feared, that we are here to protect and serve them," Bond said.

STORY: Chief Elmer Setting to leave New Castle County Police

STORY: Police link pair to 9 burglaries in NCCo

And as the first black chief, he said minority representation throughout the department is important in the "current climate" of distrust toward police.

"Hopefully, those individuals will be able to look at me and the accomplishments I have had over the course of my career and they can see as an African American, Hispanic or any minority, that law enforcement is a viable option and platform to make a difference in the community," Bond said.

Public Safety Director Joseph Bryant, who oversees ambulance, police and emergency communication divisions for county government and was also the first black person to hold that position, noted Tuesday's announcement took place in the Corporal Robert L. Snow Conference Room, named after county police's first black officer.

"It was important for us to have this ceremony in this room today because of Vaughn Bond, he is an extraordinary person, he has a heart of gold and he lives and breathes this agency," Bryant said.

Bryant said Bond's appointment will aid in the constant struggle to ensure the force's rank and file accurately reflect the diversity of the county.



New Castle County Council will have to approve the appointment in the coming weeks.

County Councilman Jea Street described Tuesday's announcement as "wonderful" and historic." He said a combination of smarts and empathy has made Bond successful.

"He is an outstanding policeman. He is dedicated and committed but he is also a people person," Street said. "He combines police expertise and a sincere compassion for people."

Bond's father, Vaughn Bond Sr., said he's proud of his son becoming the first minority to lead the force, but his work is what makes him really smile.

"I look at the fact he was taught by the department, he learned to work hard and he really earned it," the elder Bond said. "I don't really get into a black-white thing. I get into a man being a man."

search_result.title: DSU president: 'It isn't what we say or think that defines us, but what ...
search_result.text:
Tony Allen

Special to the USA TODAY Network

On Jan. 18, Delaware State University students expressed themselves fully — and without equivocation — on sexual assault in our University community. Their protest was clear and unifying. Our students demanded more be done — to educate the entire University and to ensure our preparedness when they need us most.

I am thankful our students exercised their collective voice so powerfully. The next day, at a town hall that lasted more than eight hours, and in subsequent meetings, I heard of the sobering reality and painful trauma survivors face. To all who have shared over the past few weeks, I appreciate your bravery and strength.

We have heard you and are taking action.

The first among many new initiatives is the forming of the Safe Space Coalition and nine committees aimed at formulating strategies, solutions, and processes.

For subscribers:Delaware State students aren’t fighting for campus safety. So what's next?

The Safe Space Coalition brings to bear the university community’s expertise and talent among faculty, students, alumni, and parents alike. They will review our current practices and develop solutions on both the prevention and education side of the issue as well as the victim support and treatment side. The Safe Space Coalition is led by Dr. Gwen Scott-Jones, Dean of the Wesley College of Health and Behavioral Sciences, and senior social work major and Student Government Association Treasurer Rita Williams. Core team members are listed here.

Additionally, nine new committees will tackle specific elements of concern, working in conjunction with the Coalition. Committees are:

Employee Awareness and Safety

Campus Health

Counseling and Prevention

Judicial Affairs and Title IX

Communications and Customer Service

Facilities Management

Project Resources and Funding

Public Safety

Student Awareness, Engagement, and Safety

We have also communicated the following:

Naming Deputy Chief of University Public Safety Joi Simmons as the Sexual Assault Awareness Officer. Deputy Chief Simmons has extensive training in sexual assault education, investigations, and victim / survivor services.

Extending counseling hours to 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. Monday through Friday, and from 9 a.m. to noon Saturdays, and making virtual health services available through ChristianaCare-GoHealth Urgent Care,https://www.gohealthuc.com/dte/christianacare/desu.

Ensuring that our Public Safety escort service is available 24/7.

Upgrading our security to include lighting throughout the main campus and DSU Downtown, including the emergency blue lights system.

Establishing a Center for Safety & Well-being to better integrate our resources across campus.

Adding body cameras for the Public Safety Team.

Broadening our camera utilization on campus and in the residence halls.

Enhancing our special support groups for students who are survivors and/or allies.

Convening the first in a series of mandatory sensitivity trainings for the entire University Community throughout the remainder of the semester.

I want to emphasize that these are initial steps aimed at immediately improving our current practices.

We will work closely with the Coalition and committees as we build out our long-term plan. Equally important will be regular reporting to the broad University community, which will happen monthly for the foreseeable future. I also want to be clear on one final point. After a comprehensive review of each case, those who are found responsible for sexual assault will be expelled from the University and referred to the Attorney General’s office.

No words will ever suffice in moments like these, only actions–actions that reflect a seriousness of accountability.

Tony Allen is the president of Delaware State University.

search_result.title: Campaign launched to light up Dover's high-crime areas
search_result.text:
When Lamotte McCallister opened his front door to four people wearing fluorescent yellow shirts bearing the phrase "Lights-On Dover Strong," he didn't know what to expect.

When he heard why they were there, he was all in.

The volunteers were among a group going door to door providing residents in central Dover energy-efficient LED lights for their front porches and solar-powered LED motion-sensor floodlights for their backyards. It is part of an effort to reduce crime in an area that has historically seen the highest numbers.

Under the program, residents on 14 streets – including New, Queen, Kirkwood, Bradford and Governors streets – can get the free lights if they pledge to turn them on every night.

"The goal is to increase security and empower residents to increase public awareness of criminal activity in these high-risk areas," said Chanda Jackson, community engagement specialist for Restoring Central Dover. "Neighbors working together and talking to each other creates a sense of community. We hope it will demonstrate a unified community approach to public safety."

Volunteers from the HELP Initiative Inc. and the Restoring Central Dover, along with interns from Delaware State University, have been out all week installing the lightbulbs and motion floodlights on houses whose owners signed a pledge to reduce crime during a kickoff block party at the end of June.

STORY: Three state hospital workers charged after patient dies

STORY: Smyrna hires firm to investigate police chief

The boots-on-the-ground effort also approaches owners in houses that are not already signed up to try to get full neighborhood participation. McCallister fell into that category.

"This is amazing," said McCallister, who lives on South Queen Street. "I didn't know this was happening, but I think it might help deter people from going in backyards. I think this will help decrease crime in the area."

That's the hope of the Dover Police Department, a community partner in the campaign. Dover Police Chief Marvin Mailey Jr. believes the effort is a great prevention tool in some of the city's high-risk neighborhoods.

The area around South New Street, South Governors Avenue, South Bradford Street and South Kirkwood Street has seen more than its share of crime and is considered one of the worst areas in the city, he said.

Mailey said people there want to have a better quality of life.

"Typically, this is our high-crime area, and we are trying to change the landscape of the city," Mailey said. "This program will definitely make Dover safer. Our bad guys don't like to stand under lights when they commit crimes."

According to Dover police data, burglaries and robberies rose by double-digit percentages in 2016, as were violent crimes, including murder, rape, robbery and aggravated assault. A large number of those crimes are occurring in the campaign's target area, Mailey said.

When the campaign was first discussed publicly in April, the goal was to reach 200 homes in a 75-block area. That number is now 500 homes, according to Jackson. She estimates the cost for materials is $9,000, with the labor being donated by volunteers.

Jackson said a number of partners have pledged money and labor, including the HELP Initiative Inc., Delaware State University, NCALL Research Inc., Habitat for Humanity of New Castle County, Delaware Sustainable Energy Utility, the Home Depot and Dover police.

"This is a community effort and the residents seem pretty receptive. So far, we've had positive reaction to the campaign," she said. "We're getting calls from residents asking when they can get their bulbs. It's a matter of breaking the ice and building relationships."

Charlie Kistler and Harold Stafford have been providing the installation labor this past week and will continue their efforts until all the houses in the target area have bulbs and motion sensors. Along the way, the founders of the HELP Initiative Inc. have been educating homeowners about the campaign and also about energy efficiency in general.

"The residents commit to leaving the lights on and also to keeping their neighbors aware that it is important to keep their lights on, too," Kistler said. "When we go from house to block to neighborhood and then the city, we want to light it up to the point where we can reduce crime."

But the effort is about more than crime, Jackson said.

Restoring Central Dover was adopted in 2014 as a comprehensive neighborhood revitalization plan. Jackson said the plan represents the community’s vision for restoring the vitality of Central Dover and lists recommendations for implementation over the next 10 years.

Resident input and priorities have been derived from a community survey, meetings, events, activities and community outreach, she said.

"Lights-On Dover Strong is just a piece of the puzzle," she said. "Relationships are important in this campaign and all of our efforts. If we don't trust each other, nothing will change."

Reach Jerry Smith at jsmith17@delawareonline.com. Follow him on Twitter at @JerrySmithTNJ.

search_result.title: Slain Delaware state trooper's wife: He gave his life to his job
search_result.text:
Brittany Horn

The News Journal

Cpl. Stephen J. Ballard may not have always worn his Delaware State Police uniform, but he was always on duty, his wife Louise said.

"He gave, literally, his life to this job," she said in an interview with The News Journal. "But when he was living, he gave his life each day to Delaware and the community he served."

Ballard was gunned down Wednesday in a Bear-area Wawa parking lot when he approached a suspicious vehicle and the passenger jumped out and began firing at him. Ballard fell after being hit, and the shooter continued to fire rounds into the trooper before fleeing to his family's Middletown-area home.

The shooter was identified as 26-year-old Burgon Sealy Jr., who was shot dead by police 21 hours after emerging from the barricaded home that was largely destroyed by explosive charges used to break down windows and doors. Sealy appeared armed with a weapon after an armored vehicle ripped siding off the structure.

A Celebration of Life service is slated for 11 a.m. Friday at the Chase Center on the Riverfront in Wilmington. Those wishing to pay respects to his family are invited to do so from 8:30 a.m. until 10 a.m. Immediately following, uniformed emergency services personnel will be invited to pay their respects.

Friends, colleagues and family members described the 32-year-old Ballard as having a big smile and a positive nature. His wife said his willingness to help people is what attracted her to him in the first place.

WHAT HAPPENED: Standoff ends in Middletown; suspect in Delaware trooper death killed

WHO HE WAS: Trooper's friends say Delaware lost a bright light

The two met through mutual friends at the Delaware State Police, where Ballard began working 8½ years ago after graduating from Delaware State University. He was recruited by troopers to join the force right out of college, Louise Ballard said, and he graduated the academy in April 2009.

The two were married on Nov. 15, 2015, at the DuPont Country Club near Wilmington. The family had recently moved to Hockessin, and Ballard was working as a patrolman based out of Troop 2 in Glasgow.

He didn't always intend to be a state trooper, Louise said. Ballard originally started DSU in the school's aviation program with dreams of being a pilot, after serving as a Civil Air Patrol cadet in the wing’s Andrews Composite Squadron from 1998-2006.

Lt. Col. James Brogan, now chief of staff for the Nebraska Wing, previously served in the same squadron with Ballard and remembered him as a man with quiet demeanor, steadfast determination and unquestionable integrity.

“A man whose actions were consistent with his word, Stephen set an example to all around him and inspires us to be and do more in our communities," Brogan said in a release from the Civil Air Patrol National Capital Wing. "His legacy can be seen in the love shared across this nation and among those of us who had the privilege to know him. It's more than accurate to say that I learned more from Stephen than I could have ever imparted to him.”

Ballard changed his major to criminal justice after realizing he wanted to engage more with the community as a police officer rather than a pilot, his wife said. He continued to work with the university through the only collegiate chapter of the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives, or NOBLE, where he mentored about eight students.

He was also highly involved in NOBLE career fairs, fundraising events and recruiting, said Delaware Chapter President Director Joseph Bryant Jr., adding that Ballard touched many lives within the organization.

"He had an infectious smile and caring spirit with a kind and giving heart," Bryant said in a statement. "While we know we have lost a member of the law enforcement community, we have truly lost a member of our family."

In lieu of flowers at the funeral, Ballard's family has requested donations be made in his memory to NOBLE.

The outpouring of love and support for the Delaware State Police and Ballard's family in the days after his death would have made him even prouder to be a trooper, Louise Ballard said. This camaraderie and willingness to serve and support each other was the reason he wore the uniform, she said.

"He wanted to help people in the best way," Louise Ballard said. "Out of the kindness of his heart, if he wanted to help someone, he would do that. Personally, that was his nature; it's who he was."

Ballard's love for people spilled over into his personal life, where he helped his wife raise their 5-year-old daughter, Abigail. Many who knew him immediately described him as a family man who put his wife and daughter first.

RELATED: A harrowing night in Middletown-area neighborhood

RELATED: Wilmington 5K run honors fallen police officers

State police created a memorial fund to help his family at the Delaware State Police Federal Credit Union. Checks can be made out to the DSTA-Stephen Ballard Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 168, Cheswold, DE 19936.

All Wawa locations in Delaware will also be collecting donations for Ballard's memorial fund, and the company pledged to match the first $50,000 in customer donations. A small memorial service will be held at 10 a.m. Monday at the Pulaski Highway location, which has been closed since Ballard was killed there.

But underneath the badge and uniform, Ballard was human, too, Louise said.

He loved to travel, even if it was only up to Philadelphia to catch dinner and a show. Every year, she said, they tried to take a new trip together and see another part of the world.

He was also a fan of gardening, she admitted with a laugh.

"He actually really enjoyed cutting the grass," Louise Ballard said. "He was very proud of his lawn."

And he never passed up the opportunity to make better the world he lived in, she said. He would often cover costs of dry cleaning or car repairs for friends who needed help.

Once he stopped to counsel a young woman driving erratically when he was off duty in his trooper SUV, Louise recalled. He was on his way to the gym when he pulled her over, she said, but he wanted her to be safer and make others on the road safer, too.

"He cared about Delaware," she said. "This is the only job he's had and he's known, and he really took it seriously. He respected the job. ... He had a lot of good friends on the force. And I know he's going to be terribly missed."

Contact Brittany Horn at (302) 324-2771 or bhorn@delawareonline.com. Follow her on Twitter at @brittanyhorn.

search_result.title: Scope of medical data breaches unknown in Delaware
search_result.text:
Margie Fishman

The News Journal

The letter was mailed just in time for Christmas.

"We are writing to inform you of an incident at Brandywine Pediatrics ... that may have resulted in the disclosure of your personal information, including your name and medical information," began the one-page mea culpa.

Michelle Kirton, who has two children ages 1 and 7, was one of nearly 27,000 patients, parents and guardians who received the notice nearly two months after the data breach occurred. When a health care breach occurs, it doesn't mean that a patient's identity is necessarily stolen, only that the information is left unsecured for a period of time.

The Wilmington mom, like others, knew it wasn't good news, but she also didn't fully understand the repercussions.

"I guess I should know but I don't, " acknowledged Kirton, who works as a professional organizer. "I'm just kind of surviving each day with my kids."

A growing crime, medical record-pilfering represents the next frontier of identity theft. As the modern medical workforce increasingly shares information electronically, hackers can use ransomware to hijack hospital records by encrypting patient data, and then demand payment to have it returned. Employee negligence, insecure mobile devices and use of public cloud services all threaten the security of highly sensitive information.

In 2015 alone, more than 100 million health care records were compromised nationwide –– more than one-third of all computer security breaches that year. Virtually all the exposed health information stemmed from three attacks on insurance providers: Anthem Inc., Premera Blue Cross and Excellus Health Plan Inc.

"If you have somebody's electronic record, you own that person," said Robert Lord, co-founder and CEO of Protenus, a Baltimore-based patient privacy monitoring platform. "There is a huge incentive to get this data."

Health care systems, which rely on updated medical information in life-or-death decision-making, lack the money and resources to manage breaches estimated to cost the industry $6.2 billion a year, according to security experts. A Protenus study found that the number of data breaches nearly doubled from 2015 to 2016, averaging more than one data breach per day.

Compounding the problem, government monitoring efforts vary considerably by state, and thieves can use medical information for a longer period of time and for a broader range of nefarious purposes than credit card information. Among the possibilities: Racking up expenses for medical services and devices, insurance reimbursements and prescription drugs under someone else's name; filing false tax returns; opening up credit cards; and setting up phony medical clinics.

Patients, particularly children, aren't always alerted to a problem until months or years down the road when they go to apply for a first credit card or car loan, according to Lord. By that point, their health records could be riddled with inaccurate information.

Story: TransPerfect workers victimized in data breach

The situation is especially troubling in Delaware, one of a minority of states nationwide where healthcare organizations aren't required to notify state government agencies, including the attorney general, about medical security breaches. The First State's security breach law hasn't been updated in more than a decade; during that time, the AG's Consumer Protection Unit, which is empowered to enforce data breach notification standards, hasn't filed a single enforcement action, according to office spokesman Carl Kanefsky.

"Although [the Department of Justice's] legal authority over data breaches is limited, DOJ believes that data breaches should be taken very seriously by companies or organizations whose data is compromised," he said.

Maryland's AG, by contrast, has required two health care providers to pay penalties totaling $120,000, improve security practices and pay for patients' identity theft monitoring services under settlements for medical records data breaches dating to 2013, according to office spokeswoman Christine Tobar.

Unlike more than a dozen other states, Delaware's law primarily focuses on financial identity theft; it doesn't include medical records or insurance information under the definition of protected personal information, which triggers public notification requirements in the event of a breach. Instead, the state defers to federal law, which mandates that health care providers notify affected individuals of a data breach within 60 days.

Yet a 2015 survey of medical identity theft victims by the Ponemon Institute found that only about a quarter of people are directly notified after a breach.

Once alerted, medical identity theft victims spend an average of $13,500 and 200 hours to rectify the situation, the privacy think tank found.

In the past two years, Delaware has made strides in protecting the privacy of website and mobile app users, children, students and crime victims. But medical records privacy has taken a back seat, according to Wilmington attorney Carl "Chuck" N. Kunz III.

Kunz, who specializes in data privacy issues, identified several "shortcomings" in Delaware's current law, including the AG's narrow enforcement authority and the absence of a specific timeline for notifying affected patients.

"Speaking as a consumer, I'd like to be notified as soon as I reasonably could," Kunz said. "Nothing's changed (in Delaware law) for the last 10 years and there's been a lot of activity."

Back in 2013, in response to rapidly changing technology, several members of the General Assembly attempted to strengthen Delaware's digital data breach law by expanding the definition of personal information, broadening the AG's authority to help affected individuals recoup money, and requiring companies to pay $1,000 per breach per person, even if no actual damages could be proven. The bill died in committee and has yet to be reintroduced.

Rep. Paul Baumbach, a Newark Democrat and bill co-sponsor, said the legislation didn't move forward because it was introduced late in the session.

"It probably is overdue looking at that," he said, explaining that former Rep. Darryl Scott, a Dover Democrat, was the General Assembly's technology expert.

"Without that champion there, we are less proactive and more reactive," added Baumbach, who holds bachelor's and master's degrees in computer science.

The bill's primary sponsor, Sen. Dave Sokola, another Newark Democrat, declined a request for a phone interview on the topic. In an email to The News Jounral, Sokola said cybersecurity issues are top-of-mind and "I'm open to suggestions on how to strengthen Delaware's laws to protect our citizens against data breaches going forward."

Recently, one state agency entered the fray. Responding to about 10 customer complaints, Delaware's new Insurance Commissioner Trinidad Navarro launched an investigation this month into a security breach involving Summit Reinsurance Services and BCS Financial Corporation. Summit and BCS are both subcontractors of Highmark Blue Cross Blue Shield of Delaware.

Summit voluntarily reported the breach to Attorney General Matt Denn's office this month. The Indiana-based company disclosed that ransomware had infected a server containing personal information, such as names, Social Security numbers, health insurance information and medical records of roughly 19,000 Delaware consumers. The unauthorized access occurred back in March and wasn't discovered until August, according to a recent letter that Summit sent to affected patients.

Story: 19,000 Delaware Blue Cross Blue Shield members' data breached

Under the Delaware Insurance Code, the insurance commissioner has the authority, with reasonable cause, to investigate the conduct of insurance companies and levy sanctions or fines against those violating the law.

"The commissioner runs a very consumer-centric office," office spokesman Vince Ryan explained. "He feels that any instance that could put someone or someone's personal information at risk is significant and noteworthy of this office's attention."

Yet Navarro's office isn't empowered to investigate data breaches involving health care providers, such as Brandywine Pediatrics' breach last year.

According to a Dec. 23 letter sent to nearly 27,000 current and former patients, the Brandywine breach occurred on Oct. 25 when a file server was attacked and encrypted by a "computer virus." That led an "unauthorized person" to possibly access children's names, addresses and medical records, but not Social Security numbers of payment information, the letter said.

"The is no evidence that any information was taken," according to the letter, which was faxed to The News Journal at 4:33 p.m. the Friday before Christmas — just in time to meet the federal notification deadline. The Silverside Road practice also posted a notice on its website and set up a toll-free number to field patient concerns.

Practice staff declined The News Journal's request for a phone interview. In a recent email, Jerald Eng, one of Brandywine's eight doctors, wrote that he had heard no complaints from patients regarding stolen data and "a culprit has not been identified." The practice, which had never before experienced a data breach in its 25-year history, has since hired a new IT firm to bolster its firewalls and virus protection, Eng said.

In a separate email to The News Journal, practice manager Fran Davenport wrote that the office took two months to notify patients due to a lengthy investigation by a computer forensics expert. While Brandywine Pediatrics notified other state attorneys general who had residents affected by the breach, Delaware has no such requirement, she said.

Even though her four children's medical information may be floating around somewhere, Lisa Creegan says she will remain a client of the practice. Creegan, a teacher, says she loves the doctors and wasn't alarmed that her kids' medical information might have been exposed.

"This happens to my credit card or debit card all the time," she said.

Scope of problem unknown

Creegan's reaction is considered typical; consumers have become accustomed to data breaches at retailers, hotels and restaurants over the last two years, but they often don't realize that medical records are considerably more valuable on the black market than credit card numbers, according to security experts.

"The tools and the hackers are getting more sophisticated," said Michael Vatis, a New York attorney who has specialized in data breaches for more than two decades. It's rare for a government agency to charge financial penalties for health care data breaches, according to Vatis. More often, a provider or insurer is asked to invest in better technology to avoid future problems.

Story: In secret deal, city employee gets payout

Security experts recommend educating employees on how to respond to data breaches, using automated technology to track user and system activity in real-time, encrypting data and maintaining up-to-date software.

The Office for Civil Rights under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has the authority to fine a company from $100 to $50,000 for each failure to uphold privacy standards. An individual who intentionally violates federal law and attempts to profit from medical information can face more substantial fines and jail time.

While HHS has been criticized for lax enforcement, last year was a notable exception. The department entered into a $5.55 million settlement agreement with Illinois-based Advocate Health Care Network — the largest to date against a single entity — for multiple data breaches involving more than four million individual records.

The Office for Civil Rights also maintains a "wall of shame" portal, tracking more than 1,800 health care data breaches involving at least 500 individuals since 2009.

Listed among the top 10 (by number of people affected) is Jacksonville, Florida-based Nemours Children's Health System. In 2011, Nemours reported a data breach affecting 1.6 million patients, vendors and employees at Nemours facilities in four states, including Delaware. A locked cabinet containing unencrypted computer backup tapes with billing and payroll data was reported missing from a Wilmington facility after a remodeling project. At the time, Nemours representatives said there was no evidence the tapes were stolen or the information was misused.

Following the incident, the health system invested in staff training and upgraded encryption services. Nemours Chief Information Security Officer David Jollow would not disclose the total amount spent on improvements.

"If it's encrypted, that's a great protection to keep it safe," he said. "It practically eliminates the risk from hackers."

To date, Nemours, which operates Alfred I. duPont Hospital for Children in Wilmington, hasn't suffered another data breach, Jollow said. He added that he has heard no complaints from patients about their information being misused.

The Nemours breach occurred in Delaware and it was massive, yet it wasn't voluntarily reported to the Delaware AG and isn't listed among Delaware breaches in the federal portal.

In Delaware, unlike in California and other states, there's no one-stop shop to review all the medical data breaches affecting residents.

Pulling together information from state and federal governments and from newspaper archives, The News Journal found more than a half-dozen medical data breaches involving Delaware companies and residents over the last five years.

Prior to the Summit breach, three others were voluntarily reported to the Delaware AG over the past five years, affecting a total of 258 residents.

Three additional breaches appeared in the HHS portal, including the Brandywine Pediatrics breach and a 2014 breach involving Lewes-based Beebe Physicians Network. In the Beebe breach, a temporary contractor who had previously been arrested for identity theft, had handled protected health information of more than 1,800 individuals, according to the federal directory.

In response to a News Journal request, spokespeople for Christiana Care Health System and Bayhealth Medical Center said their systems had not suffered data breaches in the last five years.

Internal employees, not outside hackers, are responsible for about 40 percent of all health record breaches, according to Lord. Last year, a former employee of Wilmington-based Ambucor Health Solutions downloaded health information affecting more than 1,600 people before leaving the company, according to the federal portal.

In August, nearly 150,000 Delaware Medicaid clients enrolled in Highmark Health Options were notified of a May cyber attack that potentially compromised their health plan information, including member ID and Medicaid numbers.

Richard Grzybowski of Elsmere was among the notified patients. Now, the 58-year-old regularly checks his medical payment history for discrepancies. So far, he has found none.

The same day The News Journal published its story on the Highmark breach, the 58-year-old said his insurance company called him to verify his medical history.

Grzybowski refused. The way the system currently functions, patients must keep sensitive information close to the vest, he said.

"Who is responsible?" he wondered aloud. "I feel like somebody should fix this."

Contact Margie Fishman at 302-324-2882, on Twitter @MargieTrende or mfishman@delawareonline.com.

Recent medical data breaches affecting Delaware patients

2017: Delaware Insurance Commissioner Trinidad Navarro launches an investigation into a security breach involving Summit Reinsurance Services and BCS Financial Corporation, after ransomware infected a server containing personal information, such as names, Social Security numbers, health insurance information and medical records of roughly 19,000 Delaware consumers.

2016: In late December, Brandywine Pediatrics notifies nearly 27,000 patients, parents and guardians about an October data breach that occurred after a file server was attacked and encrypted by a "computer virus." That led an "unauthorized person" to possibly access children's names, addresses and medical records, but not Social Security numbers of payment information.

2016: In August, nearly 150,000 Delaware Medicaid clients enrolled in Highmark Health Option are alerted to a May cyber attack that potentially compromised their health plan information, including member ID and Medicaid numbers.

2014: A temporary Beebe Physicians Network contractor, who had previously been arrested for identity theft, is found to have handled protected health information of more than 1,800 individuals.

2014: Visionworks, an eye care service provider, reports two medical data breaches affecting a total of 257 Delaware residents

2011: Nearly 500 maternity patients at Saint Francis Hospital in Wilmington have their personal health care information potentially compromised when a doctor loses a thumb drive for as long as two weeks.

2011: The names and Social Security numbers of 113 patients are stolen from a Beebe Medical Center employee, after the employee brought a cost report on vacation to Florida.

2011: Florida-based Nemours Children's Health System reports a data breach affecting 1.6 million patients, vendors and employees at Nemours facilities in four states, including Delaware. A locked cabinet containing unencrypted computer backup tapes with billing and payroll data is reported missing from a Nemours facility in Wilmington after a remodeling project.

(Source: Delaware Department of Justice, News Journal archives and U.S. Department of Health & Human Services)

search_result.title: Wilmington firefighter deaths are first in 18 years
search_result.text:
Karl Baker, Esteban Parra, and Xerxes Wilson

The News Journal

Two firefighters were killed in a Canby Park rowhouse blaze early Saturday.

The fire was in the 1900 block of Lakeview Road.

The last death of a Wilmington firefighter was 18 years ago.

Two longtime firefighters were killed when a floor in a Canby Park rowhouse gave way in an intense fire early Saturday, injuring four others in what Chief Anthony Goode called "a very tragic day for the Wilmington Fire Department." The incident is the first death of a city firefighter in almost two decades.

Lt. Christopher Leach, 41, a 14-year veteran, and Senior Firefighter Jerry Fickes, 51, a 13-year veteran, died in the fire. Both men had children and families, Goode said at a press conference Saturday.

Firefighters Ardythe Hope and Brad Speakman were transported to Crozer-Chester Medical Center in Upland, Pennsylvania, and were in critical but stable condition Saturday evening.

Two other injured firefighters, Terrance Tate and John Cawthray, were treated at Christiana Hospital and discharged Saturday afternoon.

Cawthray thanked well-wishers on Facebook, and noted Leach and Fickes "paid the ultimate sacrifice."

"I was lucky, I came away with only 2nd degree burns on my wrist and hand," he said. "I truly loved both of them and they will be missed. Keep their families in mind."

The fire was reported 2:54 a.m. at 1927 Lakeview Road, in a neighborhood of brick rowhouses about a block south of South Union Street. Firefighters arrived to find flames shooting out of windows and doorways.

Remembrances for Wilmington firefighters killed

Information sought: Wilmington line of duty deaths

"It was a huge pile of fire coming out of the front door," said a neighbor who goes by Ed and declined to provide his last name. "I said to myself, 'How the hell are (firefighters) going to get in there.'"

According to the Fire Department, one or more firefighters became trapped at 3:14 a.m. and radioed for help. Dozens of firefighters responded and searched, officials said. They also used ladders to access the upper story of the rowhouse, where the fire shot through the roof and sent flames and thick smoke into the night sky.

Fire Department Battalion Chief James Jobes said firefighters were working on the first floor when it collapsed, trapping them in the basement. Their bodies were removed and taken to the state medical examiner's office in downtown Wilmington by a motorcade that was saluted by emergency personnel lining the streets.

"This is a tragic situation," said Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams. "My heart is heavy. So much pain right now."

The residents of the home were able to escape.

Missy Napier lived in the home with her five children, all between 10 and 17 years old. Another child, a family friend, was staying with the family. When she first noticed smoke, she scrambled to get all of the kids out of the home, she said.

"We started hollering, 'Get out of the house get out of the house,'" she said between tears Saturday morning. "We ran out back but the smoke was so hot. Not the fire, but the smoke was burning your face."

Napier's mother, Debbie Napier, suspects firefighters thought someone was trapped, "but everybody got out."

"It's breaking her heart that they passed away in her house," she said.

Debbie Napier called her son, Tom Roth, as the fire raged. He arrived outside of his sister's house to find tall flames. By the afternoon, Roth, still stunned, sat in a folding chair a block away from the home alongside an ambulance.

He said the family had been celebrating the beginning of the weekend when the fire started. At first, they didn’t realize its magnitude, he said.

“The adults were doing what adults do on a Friday night, listening to music having a couple of beers. Some of the kids were out riding their bikes right here,” Roth said. “The smoke hit them just dead in the face.”

Neighbors on Saturday comforted one another on the narrow one-way street, developed as part of the Canby Park Estates subdivision 70 years ago. The side-by-side homes take up the entire block from Rodman Road to South Union Street, with an alley behind it.

New Castle County property records show 1927 Lakeview Road was built in 1944. The 1,075-square-foot property had three bedrooms.

Shane Henry, who lives with his fiancé in the basement of a row house next to the Napier home, said smoke enveloped the surrounding houses.

“Out of nowhere, we saw a black cloud of smoke pour down into our room,” Henry said. “We thought it was maybe our roommates, maybe they left a cigarette still lit. But it was pouring too much, we knew something was wrong."

Henry and his fiancé , unable to go home because of fire damage, now have nowhere to sleep, he said.

At about the same time that Henry noticed the fire, another neighbor, Johnny Alvarado, saw Napier’s children running down Lakeview Road away from the burning home.

“First, you see the black smoke going up, then flames,” he said. “Smoke flooded the streets.”

Alvarado began knocking on neighbors' doors telling them to get away in case the blaze were to spread. He wasn’t the only neighbor to jump into action.

Claudia Leon lives across the street from the Napier home and awoke to a woman banging on her front door in the early hours of the morning.

“She came to the door yelling, ‘Everybody get out — a fire broke out,” Leon said.

More than 12 hours after Leon had been warned of the blaze, the smell of smoke remained in the air along the block and a puddle of standing water that had flowed off of Napier's property rested at the intersection of Lakeview and Rodman Roads.

Multiple neighbors chatted in front of homes as they peered toward the exterior of the charred, brick rowhouse and its yard, enclosed by a chain link fence. An extension ladder still rested against the front of the home, reaching just below the top floor window.

The Office of the State Fire Marshal and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives are investigating the cause. The federal agency is participating because Wilmington fire officials decided to exclude themselves from the investigation, Jobes said. He said they are exploring all possibilities and foul play has not been ruled out, but he could not discuss specifics.

Leach was assigned to Ladder Co. 2. Fickes was at Squad 4 and was a member and past assistant chief at Aetna Hose, Hook & Ladder Co. in Newark.

Vice President Joe Biden visited the scene of the fire and flags were also flown at half-staff at Wilmington fire stations, which were adorned with black bunting. At Fire Station No. 6 on North Union Street near the fire, a neighbor around 1 p.m. dropped off two pizzas to show her support for the department.

"It's tragic," said the woman, who declined to give her name. "They're part of our neighborhood."

In Hockessin, the Old Lancaster Pike fire station sign read, “Prayers to our Brothers & Sisters of the Wilmington FD.”

The deaths mark the second incident that has seen a Delaware firefighter killed on the job this year.

On July 11, Tim McClanahan, a volunteer firefighter from Lewes, died after falling from a helicopter while training with the Delaware Air Rescue Team. Clanahan, 46, was a veteran emergency responder. He previously worked work for Priority 1 Rescue in Texas, which provides emergency service via helicopters to oil rigs and industry service ships in the Gulf of Mexico.

Before Saturday, the most recent Wilmington firefighter death was Prince Albert “Ali" Mousley Jr., who was 58 when he was among the first to arrive at a house fire on the 2800 block of North Tatnall Street in Jan. 6, 1998. At the scene, Mousley collapsed with a heart attack and died. He was a 27-year veteran of the force.

Goode, the Wilmington fire chief, knows well the dangers of the job. His father, Lt. James Goode Jr., died of a heart attack at a city fire station after he aided a rescue mission on the Delaware River on June 18, 1990. He was an 18-year veteran of the force.

At least 13 firefighters have died in the line of duty since the department’s first paid platoon of 50 firefighters started service in 1921.

Funeral arrangements have not been announced for Leach and Fickes.

Goode on Saturday called both men heroes.

"Please keep those children and those families and all the members of the Wilmington Fire department in your prayers," he said.
